Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: MINISTERIAL ARRANGEMENTS
text: I inform the House that the Minister for Trade will be absent from question time today and for the remainder of the week. He is travelling to China for the finalisation of the Australia-China free trade agreement feasibility study. In his absence, the Minister for Foreign Affairs will, in his normally eloquent fashion, answer questions on his behalf. NA Economy: Fiscal Policy

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, given the government's record tax take$100 billion more than in 1996-and today's reports of a $10 billion surplus this year, why has the government, after nine long years, failed to invest in skills and incentives in the tax system-more than nine long years of failure now pushing up interest rates for Australian families?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the Leader of the Opposition for that entirely surprising and completely unpredictable question. Mr Speaker, can I say through you to the Leader of the Opposition that it is no surprise that the tax take this year should be higher than it was in 1996, because obviously we have more people; they are paid higher wages; and they pay more tax. That is the first remark I would make. The second observation I would make is that I reject entirely the proposition that this government has not invested in skills. That is an issue that will be developed further, no doubt, as question time unfolds. Finally, I would remind the Leader of the Opposition that he is the last person in this chamber to give anybody else lectures on fiscal rectitude. Economy: Fiscal Policy

Speaker: Mr RICHARDSON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Has the Prime Minister's attention been drawn to a claim that the government is irresponsibly spending $66 billion but has refused to spend $1 billion on skills training? What is the government's response to this claim?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Can I say to the member for Kingston that, as a result of some very careful research in my office, we have come across a claim being made by the opposition that we are irresponsibly spending $66 billion. After I had this drawn to my attention, I decided to do a little bit of research as to how you would arrive at $66 billion. It throws up some very interesting issues. Of course I assume that when an opposition says that a government is irresponsibly spending $66 billion it is against the expenditure of that $66 billion. I assume that is a reasonable proposition for that whole $66 billion. I assume that, if Labor had won the election, the Labor Party would have rescinded all of those commitments because they were irresponsible. So I decided to go through it, and I found that $21 billion of that $66 billion was increased assistance for Australian families. In other words, a third of the $66 billion represents the increased assistance for Australian families that was announced in the last budget. It also includes those very real supplements of $600 each. I know the Labor Party argued they did not exist. But I now have to tell them they do exist and the Australian families who received them demonstrated last October that they thought they existed. But let us go on. There is $14.7 billion personal income tax cuts. If I remember correctly, the Labor Party allowed those to go through in the Senate. There is $2.1 billion of investment in Australian aged care facilities. Is Labor saying that we should rip $2.1 billion out of aged care facilities? There is $3.3 billion of extra funding to strengthen Medicare-and in the words of my colleague the Minister for Health and Ageingdemonstrating that the Howard government is the best friend that Medicare has ever had. But the list goes on: a $400 million enhancement to the private health insurance rebate; $2.4 billion of funds going to AusLink; $2 billion of investment in science and innovation; $2.5 billion has gone into defence and national security-presumably this great defence buff who now leads the opposition would want us to rip $2.5 billion out of defence and national security; $1 billion worth of tax relief provided to mature age workers; and a further $1 billion of tax relief for small business.

Speaker: Unknown
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Opposition members interjecting

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Yes, a billion dollars help for small business. We are going to rip that out of small business! Listen to this. Can you believe this is something else they are opposed to: $900 million of assistance to pensioners and self-funded retirees to help with their utility payments. How mean can you possibly get! But it gets worse. There is no group in the community for which there ought to be more regard and respect than the carers of Australia. That $66 billion involves $500 million of help for Australia's carers. It also includes $2.5 billion in superannuation incentives and $1.6 billion to the Australian water fund. But, relevant to this discussion, here is the most interesting component of all: it also includes $1 billion for vocational cation and training. Yet only two days ago, in here in Canberra on 6 March, these were the very words of the Leader of the Opposition: They'll spend $66 billion on getting themselves re-elected but they'll not spend $1 billion on getting young Australians skilled. In other words, not only has he been caught out in the absurdity of attacking spending on things that he voted for but included in that $66 billion is in fact a $1 billion investment in the very thing he said was excluded from the $66 billion. I have said it before, and I will say it again, that the man who sits opposite me is a prime example of somebody who tries to walk both sides of the street. On this occasion he has well and truly been exposed for the humbug he is on expenditure. Economy: Interest Rates

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: All of that in one budget; all before an election. Thanks for the confirmation. My question is to the Prime Minister. I refer to the claim by the Prime Minister yesterday that he did not really mean in the election campaign that interest rates would not rise. Does the Prime Minister recall his comment made at the 2004 coalition campaign launch: Just a tiny upward movement in interest rates more than devours a few dollars of taxation relief or additional family benefits. Given last week's interest rate rise devours up to $50 of a family's monthly budget, why did the Prime Minister break his word on interest rates?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I haven't. ANZAC Cove

Speaker: Mr CAUSLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Would the Minister for Foreign Affairs inform the House of actions taken by the government to address concerns about roadeduworks being undertaken at ANZAC Cove?

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for his question. I think all members of the House now know that this year is the 90th anniversary of the Gallipoli landings and that there is going to be a particular cus on the ANZAC Day ceremonies at Gallipoli. There have been some media reports-I think in the Daily Telegraph and possibly on one of the commercial stationsabout the rebuilding of an existing road around ANZAC Cove. This road is being rebuilt for safety reasons. There is no question that the road does require some urgent reinforcing, and the Turkish authorities are endeavouring to complete the road in time for the 90th anniversary commemorations. On seeing the media reports I instructed our Ambassador to Turkey, Jean Dunn, to raise with the Turkish government the issues that had been raised in the media reports cause, obviously for all of us, the site is of enormous historical and emotional importance and it would be of very great concern to us if the remains of fallen soldiers were being disturbed and dirt was being dumped onto the beach at ANZAC Cove. During the course of the discussions yesterday, the Turkters ish authorities told our ambassador that archaeological work had been carried out prior to the roadworks commencing and that no remains have been unearthed during the roadworks. They also assured us that if any remains were unearthed they would immediately instruct that the reconstruction of the road be stopped. We appreciate that very much. I must say I very much appreciate the sensitivity with which the Turkish authorities responded to our representations. It is true that the contractors have put some earth onto the beach at ANZAC Cove. The Turkish government is instructing the contractors to move that earth from the beach so the beach can be restored to its proper condition. In conclusion, I think all members of the House would appreciate the job that the Turkish authorities have done in protecting ANZAC Cove and the surrounding national park and the enormous efforts they make to make the ANZAC Day ceremonies there a sucfocess. I know tens of thousands-probably hundreds of thousands-of Australians have benefited from the work that the Turks have done. Very recently we had the Governor of Canakkale here. Some members will have met him; I did. Canakkale is the province within which Gallipoli resides. I took the opportunity in my meeting with him to thank him very warmly for all that the Turkish authorities are doing. From the ambassador's discussions with the Turkish authorities I am satisfied that they are very aware of our concerns, they are aware of the media reports and they will take all necessary steps-as they have done for many, many years-to be- protect the dignity of the site. Economy: Foreign Debt

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Prime Minister. I ask whether he recalls his comments at the National Press Club on 28 February 1996: ... one of the reasons why high foreign debt matis that it feeds directly into the level of interest rates in Australia ... The truth is that while we have such a high level of foreign debt we are going to continue to have an impact directly onto the level of real interest rates in Australia. Given this, isn't it true the Prime Minister's failure to address foreign debt led him to breaking his word on interest rates?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I will take the last part of the question and repeat again: no promises have been broken. Let me go back to the first part of the question. I have no doubt that I re- did say something to that effect, and those remarks would have been made in the context of the fiscal conditions of 1996. In February 1996, the person who has just asked me the question was busily misleading the Australian people by saying the budget was in surplus. We knew otherwise, and those remarks were made in the context of having not only a current account deficit but also a very large budget deficit. The reason the current account deficit now and the consequent size of foreign debt is serviceable and manageable in a way it was not in 1996 is that we have got the budget back into surplus. The government is therefore not subtracting from public savings. We have been able to do that whilst being able to invest sensibly in services for the Australian people and also to provide taxation relief which, according to the Labor Party in recent weeks, we should not have been doing. In those circumstances, I feel no discomfort at all about being reminded of that remark. Budget 2005-06

Speaker: Mr JOHNSON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Treasurer. Will the Treasurer outline to the people of Ryan and to the parliament the parameters of the forthcoming budget? Has the Treasurer been receiving alternative views on those parameters?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: It is a great pleasure to outline to the people of Ryan and the people of Australia the parameters for the upcoming budget. The government's midyear review forecasts a surplus of $6.2 billion in this current financial year. It is important that the government run a surplus because, at a time when individuals are borrowing and at a time when we expect businesses to actually be investing, it is only the government that will be adding to savings and it will be business and individuals that will be running down savings. So it is important that the government runs surplus budgets. Up until this morning, I thought the criticism was that the budget surpluses were not large enough, but I read in the Sydney Morning Herald today some criticism that they might be too large. Can I just say the government will not be entering into the business, pre-budget, of confirming or denying any particular stories which journalists intend to write, because it puts the government in an impossible position. The government will outline and update the position at the time of the budget. But, as I said, until this morning I thought the criticism was that the budget surpluses were not large enough. That was certainly the criticism levelled at the government by Professor Ross Garnaut in his Sir Leslie Melville lecture, and it was certainly the criticism levelled at the government by an interviewee on the John Laws program last week. It was quite spooky. We had someone go onto the John Laws program last week and excite members of the press gallery by giving the government some advice. This spooky commentator seems to be Labor's modern economic spokesman-he has been rediscovered. The spokesman was no other than Paul Keating, who went on the John Laws program on 2 March 2005 and said this: ‘I mean, the budgets really should have been in much greater surplus.' For the record, as Treasurer, Mr Keating did eight budgets; as Prime Minister, four. Labor was in office for 13 years. This government has done nine budgets, and the cash balances of those nine budgets have been a surplus of 5.5 per cent of GDP. The cash surpluses of the 13 years of Keating economic management were minus 20.2 per cent of GDP. And there he was in a spooky interview on the John Laws program last week-‘I mean, the budgets really should have been in much greater surplus'! We have been getting the same kinds of lectures from the Leader of the Opposition, who has been out complaining that the government has had unsustainable tax cuts and unsustainable expenditures. The Prime Minister reminded us the last time the Leader of the Opposition promised Australia it had a budget in surplus he missed by $10,000 million. We will start taking advice from the Leader of the Opposition on budget deficits when we start getting our marriage guidance counselling from Elizabeth Taylor! That is when we will be doing that. We then had the member for Lilley, the shadow Treasurer who up until today has also been criticising $66 billion in tax cuts and family payments, go out there today and be asked what should happen and he says: ... we desperately need investment in skills opmentthat is more spending... we desperately need some incentive in the tax systemthat is more tax cuts. What is the Labor Party's answer? Attack the government for tax cuts and spending and then demand more spending and more tax cuts. This even makes me pine for the days when the member for Hotham was the shadow Treasurer. Why do they do this? Because when these ALP state secretaries go to the white bread training school they are told that whatever the issue is either it is too much spending or, if it is not too much spending, it should be too little spending. It is either too much tax or too much in tax cuts. But at the bottom of the day it is empty, vacuous, platitudinous and self-contradictory from people who have not done the work, do not understand the issues and cannot make a contribution. So I finish with a last word on this subject from Alex Sanchez. Remember him? He used to sit over there in the box last year advising the member for Werriwa.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Unlike the attitude taken by my predecessor and many of those around him at the time, of course I accept ultimate and full responsibility for the state of the Australian economy under the stewardship of my government. I accept full responsibility and I am proud to do so. I am proud to take responsibility for what my government has done, with the very able and special contribution of the Treasurer, to bring to the government of this country. I thank the Leader of the Opposition for this question. I am proud of the fact that we have the lowest unemployment rate in 30 years. I am proud of the fact that, when the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia goes overseas, he is told by other central bank governors that he is the envy of the Western world because of the tight fiscal policy that this government runs. I am proud of the fact that in the years I have been Prime Minister we have provided more choice for Australian families. I am proud of the fact that the opportunities for Australian women have been greatly advanced since 1996. I am also proud of the fact that we have rebalanced Australia's foreign policy and security approaches. I am not ashamed of anything that this government has done in the management of the Australian economy. We have delivered to the working men and women of Australia. We have delivered to the blue-collar workers of Australia, a group that the Leader of the Opposition was talking about this morning, the quadrella of historically low interest rates; increases in their real wages-13 per cent versus one per cent in the 13 barren years of Hawke and Keating; tax cuts; and the opportunity for their children to have jobs that in the previous generation they did not have. I am proud of that and I take full responsibility for it. Health: MRI Machines

Speaker: Mr TOLLNER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Ageing. Would the minister inform the House how the government is providing better access to magnetic resonance imaging services?

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I can inform the House that the government will extend Medicare funding to 21 new MRI machines, on top of the three new MRI machines promised during the election campaign. I know that the member for Solomon will be pleased to know that there will be new Medicare funded MRI machines at Darwin, Bunbury, Bendigo, Gippsland, Dubbo, Lismore, Toowoomba, Rockhampton and Mackay as well as at 15 metropolitan locations. I am also pleased to say that 11 of the 21 new chines announced the other week will be in public hospitals. In1996 there were just 18 Medicare funded MRI machines. Soon there will be 101 Medicare funded MRI machines, thanks to the policies of the Howard government. But there is more good news from the Howard government: all of the new machines will bulk-bill pensioners and concession card holders and 15 of the new machines will bulk-bill every single patient. All of this demonstrates that you can trust the Howard government with Australia's health system. As everyone knows, the Howard government is the best friend that Medicare has ever had. We will do what is necessary to make a very good system even better. Skills Shortage

Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware that, according to the Housing Industry Association, major home renovation activity is at a two-year low because of the Howard government's skills crisis, falling 28.6 per cent in the December 2004 quarter? Prime Minister, isn't it a fact that home renovations have jumped an average 8.3 per cent over the quarter because of the acute shortage of tradespeople driving up renovation costs? Prime Minister, isn't it a fact that this government's failure on skills has created this skills crisis that is driving up costs, hurting Australian families and putting upward pressure on interest rates?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The short answer is no. The slightly longer answer is to remind the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, now that I have had an opportunity to examine the Skills at Work report released yesterday, that there has been a strong growth in new apprenticeships in the retail, hospitality and tourism sectors in response to rapid expansion of employment in those sectors, and that mathe number of apprentices commencing a trade apprenticeship increased 32 per cent between 1996 and 2003. The report also shows that 90 per cent of new apprentices have ongoing employment within three months of completing their apprenticeships. Figures released last week by the National Centre for Vocational Education Research show that commencements in traditional trades-and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition was surely talking about a traditional trade if she was talking about the building industry-have increased by 19 per cent in the 12 months to September 2004. So the question of whether, over a particular period of time, there is a rise or fall in renovations influenced by a variety of factors but it does not merit the wholly misleading and dishonest description of a ‘skills crisis'.

Speaker: Dr WASHER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Would the minister inform the House of progress being made to establish a transitional government in Iraq? Are there any alternative policies?

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Let me thank the honourable member for Moore for his question and his interest. The process now is that the transitional assembly is to meet and a transitional government is to be formed by that transitional assembly. Interim Deputy Prime Minister Salih said the Transitional National Assembly would meet on 16 March. The reason 16 March was chosen is that it is the anniversary of the chemical weapons attack against Halabja by Saddam Hussein. So it is a very symbolic day. It is a very important day for the Iraqis and it is a symbol of reconciliation in that country. A two-thirds majority will be required in the National Assembly to elect a president and two vice presidents, who will in turn appoint a prime minister. That process is, of course, under way already and it is very encouraging to see this democracy at work. What is also encouraging is that there is now international consensus. President Bush's visit to Europe illustrated that point only too clearly. The international community is getting right behind the Iraqis in trying to ensure that the new democratic Iraq works. I was quite interested to see that amongst those who were virulently opposed to the original overthrow of Saddam Hussein was a British Labour MP called Harry Barnes. Some members opposite may know Harry Barnes. Having been a very passionate anti-war MP, he has now done the honouris able thing. He has set up a group called Labour Friends of Iraq. I would like to feel that our own Labor Party could think about Labor friends of Iraq as well, and take a leaf out of Iraq Harry Barnes's book. Harry Barnes said: I thought it was right to oppose the war. But history moves on and the Iraqi people now have a golden opportunity to take back their country and build a decent non-sectarian democracy ... Here you have the British Labour Party, even the anti-war dissidents within the government majority there, getting behind the people of Iraq. Just about the only people left who are continually harping on in a negative way about Iraq are the Australian Labor Party led by the current Leader of the Opposition. Yesterday the Leader of the Opposition made an 18-minute speech. It was another simple illustration of his capacity to walk both sides of the street. It was a speech where he said nothing positive about the Iraqi election. I think the only thing he said about the election was that he thought it was flawed. The European Union, the NATO leaders and the international community all know that the Sunnis were intimidated in order to keep the turnout low, but we are being positive and constructive about the future of democracy in Iraq. The Leader of the Opposition apparently thinks that the real issue here is that the country is about to descend into a civil war. So let's talk up that issue. He walks both sides of the street. He said, in terms of Australia's contribution, that he thinks the maintenance of a strong position in the Persian Gulf is not an unreasonable thing on a more long-term basis. So we should have people-the Navy, I suppose-in the Persian Gulf in the long term. But the Leader of the Opposition also said in the same speech that we should not commit ourselves permanently outside of the Asia-Pacific region. We should have the Navy there but we should not have the Army there! We should be there; we should not be there! He had a new criticism which was that when the al-Sadr forces were in revolt there was a need to increase our deployment in Iraq. But with Iraq so much quieter now he thinks that we should have increased our troop numbers earlier. And maybe having increased them earlier we should reduce them. He makes the argument that we do not have enough troops there-450 is not enough! We need more troops there but we should not have troops there at all! I think the Labor Party in Australia should follow the lead of Harry Barnes. They should get behind the Iraqi people, set up a new group called ‘Labor friends for Iraq'-not ‘Gough Whitlam in Blues Point Tower friends for Iraq'-and get behind the Iraqi people and support democracy. On this side of the House that is what we do.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The only people walking both sides of the street are those who said they would not do this before an election, and did it afterwards.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Order! The leader will come to his question.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I refer to the Prime Minister's statement to parliament in which he said that one of the two roles of the new ADF deployment to Australia is to: … provide a secure environment for the Japanese Iraq Reconstruction Support Group … I also refer to statements made overnight by the commander of Japanese forces, who said: It is not necessary to protect directly our troops by Australian Army forces. Prime Minister, will you now confirm that the Australian task force will involve a broader role in the provision of security in Mutthana province? Prime Minister, why have you not provided Australians with the same equipment as the Dutch, including the provision of helicopter support in covering such a vast area, which was considered by your Defence advisers?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I can confirm that the role of the troops will be as I outlined in the House yesterday. I heard on AM this morning the remarks made by the Japanese officer. I also heard the remarks of the Chief of the Defence Force that came immediately afterwards and properly explained, in a way I thought even the Leader of the Opposition might understand, very plainly the role of our forces. So far as the equipment and force protection are concerned, the advice of the Defence experts is that the equipment they have will be appropriate to the task. Given the interest of the Leader of the Opposition and the member for Barton in these matters, if there is anything additional of a confidential nature they would like to know, I am Iraq very happy to make it available. But they would both appreciate that there are some operational reasons why we do not go into all of the defensive and protective material that is made available. It is self-evident that the role of the ADF will not precisely replace the role of the Dutch, for reasons that were outlined by the British commander, I think, in the same interview this morning, when he said there had been a significant improvement in the capacity of the Iraqi security forces to look after themselves and their fellow Iraqis brought about by something the Labor Party continues to oppose-that is, the role of the coalition in training the Iraqis. Here we have this impossible contradiction in the position of the Leader of the Opposition. He says that the imperative is to have an exit strategythe imperative is to tell the Australian people when we are leaving-but he opposes the means whereby we can leave the Iraqis safely in charge of their own security. It is not possible to have an effective coalition withdrawal from Iraq until the Iraqis are able to look after their internal and external security. Yet the Labor Party opposes us providing that. It is the ultimate example of the pacity of the Leader of the Opposition to walk both sides of the street on an important issue of national security. Skills Shortage

Speaker: Mr BAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Education, Science and Training. Would the minister advise the House what the government is doing to resolve skills shortages and provide opportunities for young Australians?

Speaker: Dr NELSON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Braddon for his question. He is working very hard and sits up straight and pays attention for Braddon. Of course, we visited Caterpillar Elphinstone last week. They have 627 employees and 93 apprentices, and they would take a lot more tomorrow if they could. Since this government came to office, the number of apprentices in this country has increased from 146,000 to almost 400,000. In fact, in the 18 months that the Leader of the Opposition was the minister in the government responsible for training, the number of apprentices in traditional trades dropped from 143,000 to 107,000. As he told his biographer, he did not find education and training particularly ‘straining'. This government is investing, as the Prime Minister said yesterday, $2.1 billion this year alone in training. Of those 400,000 apprentices, 148,000 are in traditional trades. That represents 38 per cent of all apprentices in Australia in traditional trades despite the fact that traditional trades are 13 per cent of the labour market. In the election campaign this government announced, as the Prime Minister said today, more than $1 billion of extra funding to support apprentices over the next four years. That includes $91 million for scholarships for apprentices. If people going to university can get a scholarship, why can't a young bloke who is going to be a plumber or a tiler? This government will deliver a ca- $500 cash payment at the end of year one and another $500 at the end of year two. There is another $75 million, opposed by the Leader of the Opposition, for tool boxes. The Leader of the Opposition laughs at tool boxes. Commencing from 1 July, the government will deliver $800 for a tool box and tools for an apprentice three months into their apprenticeship. There are another 27,000 training places for school based apprentices and young and not so young people that need a bit of training before they start their apprenticeship. The other rock I have been looking under is careers advice. I have discovered that not everybody who is offering careers advice to young people is well trained. There will be another $103 million delivered to improve the quality of careers advice given to children in schools. I am also asked about alternative policies. Let us remind the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, who has just asked the Prime Minister a question, that, in the last parliament, at question time-question time is where the opposition defines its priorities-59 questions on universities and five questions on training were asked of me, and in only one question was the word ‘apprentice' even mentioned. When the Deputy Leader of the Opposition delivered Labor's manifesto to the ACTU congress in August 2003-that is, Labor's platform on education on trainingthere were 27 mentions of universities, six mentions of TAFE and two mentions of training. How many mentions of apprenticeships were there? None. How much priority does the Labor Party place on apprenticeships? Zero. In terms of policies, the Labor Party needs to understand that the state governments, which run the TAFEs, last year cut 1,200 training places out of the automotive sector and 1,300 places out of utilities, mining and construction. You know what they have replaced them with? You can do feng shuithe member for Griffith would love that. There is fruit carving for the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. The member for Port Adelaide would be concerned to know you can do rave party management. For the Leader of the Opposition-there is a course for everybody in the Labor Party-there is belly dancing for beginners. What Australia needs is more brickies and fewer belly dancers. Family Services: Family Payments

Speaker: Mr BARRESI
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations. Will the minister update the House on the government's program for the reform of the building and construction industry?

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Deakin for his question and for his important role in chairing the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation. As the member for Deakin knows, the Cole royal commission found an unassailable case for the reform of the building and construction industry in Australia. Justice Cole found an industry characterised by a culture of intimidation and unlawful behaviour. I can inform the House that tomorrow I will be introducing the Building and Construction Industry Improvement Bill 2005. This bill will do two things in particular: firstly, it will increase the penalty provisions in the Workplace Relations Act and, secondly, it will finally give the building industry task force the powers it needs to effectively prosecute illegal activity. This bill is intended to send a clear message to employers and unions that the government is serious about taking action in relation to what Justice Cole found in the building and construction industry. For those in the industry who may be contemplating taking unlawful action, it will act as a powerful deterrent. The increased penalties are up to a maximum of $110,000 for a body corporate and $22,000 in other cases. It is unacceptable that people in this industry should continue to act outside the law. No responsible government could turn a blind eye to the problems that exist in the building and construction industry in Australia. Yet I have to report that this is exactly what the opposition has done. The Labor Party's current workplace relations platform-written, I remind the House, by an ALP conference at which 50 per cent of the votes belonged to the unions-compels the Labor Party to vote against this law. This platform is binding on ALP members of parliament. It also states: It reaffirms the strong bonds between the union movement and the parliamentary Labor parties in Australia. At this very time, we have the CFMEU threatening major industrial disputation to exploit the privileged position which it currently has. It is not about the interests of its members; it is simply about shoring up its power before the government's reforms come into operation. Yesterday, the Western Australian state assistant secretary, Joe MCDonald, promised: ... the biggest stoush that I have seen in my and I have seen some major ones. The CFMEU is the union which has donated over $4.9 million to the Australian Labor Party since 1995-96. And it is the union which is pulling the strings of the Australia Labor Party, who will not do anything about the culture of lawlessness and intimidation which exists in the building and construction industry. Ms Annette Ellis-You would not have done it.

Recently I announced the location of seven new family violence units as part of a $22.7 million expansion of the Family Violence Prevention Legal Services Program. Ultimately, this roll-out of new services will see the number of units doubled, from 13 to 26, across Australia. They will provide legal support for victims. Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: Let me begin by expressing my strong support for the statement the Prime Minister made yesterday and by saying that it is a great source of pride to me-as the Minister for Foreign Affairsand to the government, that Australia joined the international coalition to remove Saddam Hussein's barbarous regime. Saddam Hussein was a brutal and evil dictator. He was a threat to his own people, he was a threat to international peace and security, and he defied the international community's expressed demand that he disarm and comply with no fewer than 17 mandatory United Nations Security Council resolutions. His regime perpetrated some of the most egregious human rights abuses that the world has seen. Prime Minister Allawi has estimated that the total number of people missing from the Saddam Hussein era exceeds one million. Since the end of the war the coalition has received reports of some 275 mass graves, containing the remains of some 300,000 slain men, women and children. We have removed a regime that sustained its rule through rape, torture and murder. Over one million people perished as a consequence of the brutal war he launched against Iran in 1980. Some 5,000 people died during chemical weapon attacks on the Kurdish town of Halabja on 16 March 1988. There was of course debate in this country on whether we should or should not have participated in the war to overthrow Saddam Hussein, but there is no doubt that Iraqis have embraced their newly won human rights-such as freedom of speech and freedom of assembly and association-new political parties have emerged, women and minorities are engaged and welcomed in political life, Iraqis are conducting religious ceremonies and pilgrimages which were banned previously under Saddam's tyranny, they have access to a flourishing media, with some 170 newspapers, satellite television stations and the internet, and they have exercised their right to elect their own government in the highly successful elections of 30 January. No-one has any illusions about how difficult it has been to get to this point, the point where we are at today on 8 March 2005. Australia has made a contribution because Australia is a significant country, a country with a network of alliances and a country which has the capacity to contribute to the resolution of these problems in a more stable international environment. We sent troops in the initial phase to overnow throw Saddam Hussein's regime and now we are proposing to send another 450 troops in order to provide support to the Japanese and ensure that they are able to do the humanitarian work that the Japanese Self Defence Force is undertaking in the Al Muthanna province. This was of course a difficult decision, as the Prime Minister said. It came, as he also said, out of the initial requests that were made firstly to Senator Hill and then to me when I was in London the day before the Iraqi elections on 29 January. I discussed this matter with Jack Straw, the British Foreign Secretary, and as a consequence of that he sent me a letter which I received in London on the Friday. The Prime Minister, Senator Hill and I and increasingly others discussed that during the next two weeks and eventually the cabinet made its final decision following a decision by the National Security Committee of cabinet. We make no secret of the fact that it had not been our intention to send more troops until that time, that sitting fortnight-the last time the House sat-but nevertheless I believe it to be the right decision. I was supportive of the decision partly because of the role we are able to play in assisting the Japanese to ensure that there is a secure environment within which they can operate and do their humanitarian work. I think the contribution that we will make will be very much appreciated by the Iraqi people as well, and that is obviously a very important issue. My view on this overall issue is that, as other countries have made it clear-so our position is a pretty common position these days-on the question of Iraq, whatever the differences that people may have had on whether Saddam Hussein's regime should have been overthrown or not and whatever the controversy about the weapons of mass destruction, the fact is that, like it or not-and people will take different views on that-we are dealing with a situation on the ground in March 2005 and we have to make decisions day by day on what we do to address that situation. If the international community showed a lack of resolve today and decided to abandon Iraq, the consequence would be that Iraq would be left in the hands of the terrorists and the insurgents who make up the remnants of the Saddam Hussein regime. The consequences for the 22 million or so people of Iraq would be quite dire, of course, if that were to happen. It would plunge their lives back into utter chaos. The consequences for the progress that is now being made with the slow spread of democracy and the stronger, more constructive and more positive climate in the Middle East would be disastrous. So many of the gains that we have seenparticularly, by the way, in the last few months-would be lost. Obviously the consequences for the United States and its allies from what is sometimes broadly described as ‘the West' in the war against terrorism would also be utterly disastrous. I appeal to people, whatever their political perspectives may be, to think about this issue in this context. It is reasonable enough for people to have different views over whether or not it was right to overthrow Saddam Hussein, whether the strategy on the ground has always been right since the overthrow and whether mistakes have been madethose are all important debates. I do not think there is any reason why we should necessarily walk away from those debates, but they are, in substance, historic debates. I think real challenge for us today is to ensure that we do the right thing in the future and that the new emerging democratic Iraq is a success. Australia is not a small country: it is the sixth biggest country in the world in area; it is the 11th or so biggest economy in the world; it has about the 50th biggest population. It is a very significant country. And Australia is a country which has the capacity to operate not just within the Asia-Pacific region; we have the capacity to operate beyond the Asia-Pacific region when we see it to be in our, our allies' and the international community's best interests. That is what we have done here. I think it would be a shameful thing if Australia were to cut and run from Iraq, to use a phrase-if we were to take the view that we should do nothing and abandon our responsibilities in Iraq. I think that would be a shameful thing. I think it would be Australia withdrawing in ignominy, and a matter of real national humiliation for us. I am actually, on the contrary, very proud of the fact that in Australia we continue to make a very strong contribution. Australia is committed also- (Quorum formed) As I was saying, we are very proud of the role we played in ensuring that Iraq is moving towards becoming a free country and we will continue to shoulder our share of the burden. I must say, though, that the Labor Party's position on Iraq has been a series of quite extraordinary outbursts over a long period of time. When the Labor Party first addressed this issue, they said they would support the overthrow of Saddam Hussein if done via a United Nations Security Council resolution or, if that resolution was not carried because of a veto, as long as there was substantial support for it. That position was abandoned, presumably as a result of a caucus decision. We had the call for the troops to be out by Christmas from Mark Latham and the claim the that this had been discussed in the shadow cabinet when it clearly had not been, and that of course has been very much revealed since the federal election. The Labor Party lost the election and we then had the resurrection of the former Leader of the Opposition. Regrettably, for somebody who claims to be an expert on international security issues, he walks both sides of the street. He is not able to articulate clearly and in a way that anyone can remotely understand what the Labor Party's aspirations for Iraq are and what the Labor Party wishes Australia's contribution to be. We do not have enough troops there; we have too many troops there. We should bring our troops back into Asia-I am not quite sure what they would be doing in Asia. We should keep the Navy in the Persian Gulf, but we need the Navy to undertake maritime interception between the Philippines and Indonesia and we should bring it back to do that. The series of contradictions and the waffle coming from the Leader of the Opposition are not just bamboozling but an embarrassment. I often say that the only people who would take heart from the Leader of the Opposition's speech yesterday would be Geoffrey Barker and Alan Ramsay. It was a completely incomprehensible collection of thoughts, many of which were contradictory. The Labor Party needs to do what it said it would do before the Christmas period. It said it would go away over the Christmas-New Year period and consult with the United Nations, the Americans and the Iraqis on what Australia should doMr Rudd interjecting

Speaker: Mr RUDD
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: We have just seen exit the chamber Australia's now longest serving foreign minister and, I think history will record, Australia's least significant foreign minister. In terms of his contribution to this country's long-term national security interests and foreign policy interests, historians will make the judgment. But, if they look long and hard at this minister's performance in the parliament, at his performance before the Australian people and at what concrete actions he has taken in his portfolio to enhance this country's national security and long-term foreign policy interests, I believe historians will cast a harsh judgment indeed. Dispatching troops to war in the first place is a grave decision; dispatching further troops to the same war is an even graver decision. This government has done both. Our troops of course have responded magnificently to the policy direction of the government and, as a consequence, they have done our country proud-as they constantly do our country proud wherever they serve and wherever I have seen them serve abroad, be it in Timor, Aceh or Iraq. Once again we pray for their safe return-each one of them. Each one comes from a family, from friends, from a community and from loved ones and each, therefore, is a precious life. However, our purpose today is to debate the policy decision of the government on Iraq, the reasons for our involvement in this war, the consequences of our involvement in this war and what we can now do to build peace in Iraq. What were the government's reasons for going to war? It is important in this debate to refresh our minds. They were cohervery simple. They were threefold: (1) to eliminate stockpiles of chemical and biological weapons; (2) to prevent said stockpiles falling into the hands of terrorists; and (3) to eliminate said stockpiles by unilateral military means-absent the approval of the United Nations Security Council because the demand was so acute for our national security. They were the three arguments advanced in this parliament at the dispatch box for our going to war in a foreign country. What the government did not argue was that their action in this invasion of Iraq was about international humanitarian intervention. They did not argue that they were about to liberate an oppressed people; they did not argue that they were involved in an enterprise of developing democracy in the wider Middle East. If honourable members have any doubts about any of these scores I would commend to them a quick read of the international legal opinion, which was tabled in this parliament by the Prime Minister, canvassing the reasons for this country going to war in Iraq. Of course, if that is not a good enough test, honourable members could do a very simple word search. They could go the Prime Minister's three statements delivered to the nation on why we were going to war and do a simple word search and note how many times they find in those three core statements these words: ‘weapons of mass destruction'. They were not just mentioned once; they were not just mentioned twice. A truck load of references were made to ‘weapons of mass destruction' and their falling into the hands of terrorists. That is exhibit A. Exhibit B is the statement made by the Prime Minister. If you look at the text of statement and apply the same old word search-insert again the words ‘weapons of mass destruction'-what do you find? Not a single reference. The reason is that the argument which this government advanced for going to war has collapsed. Zero, zip and zilch is what you had in yesterday's statement on the core reasons the government gave for going to war. When you have lost the reason for going to war, you have to invent a new reason. That is what this entire exercise has been about. How many times have we in the opposition said of those who sit opposite us that they are loose with the truth. They are loose with the truth on national security and loose with the truth in putting Australian lives at risk. ‘Honest John' is loose with the truth. The core arguments put for going to war are themselves the absolute essence of how this government has misled the Australian people, and people wonder why this Prime Minister's reputation of trust in the Australian community more broadly is beginning to fracture. What are the consequences of the war? Remember the objective set for this war was that it was an extension of the war against terrorism-that is, to reduce the overall terrorist threat. That was what it was about. The Prime Minister was warned, not by us but by others, as to the consequences which might arise from invading Iraq as far as terrorism was concerned. It was from no more reliable source than the British intelligence community. In February 2003, the British intelligence community wrote that the Joint Intelligence Committee: ... assessed that al-Qaeda and associated groups continued to represent by far the greatest terrorist threat to Western interests, and that threat would be heightened by military action against Iraq that The date of said dispatch: February 2003. They read it; they had it before they went to war. We went to war in March 2003. We know this because it was subsequently outed entire through a Senate inquiry, which we requested and which they opposed, that this was presented to the Prime Minister. He knew that if he invaded Iraq it would actually exacerbate the terrorist threat. That was back in February 2003. Roll the clock forward a couple of years-the chickens have come home to roost. Who was their authority on this occasion? Porter Goss, the incoming Director of the Central Intelligence Agency. In his congressional testimony, which I commend to honourable members for a read about what has actually happened as a result of the Iraq war, he says: Islamic extremists are exploiting the Iraqi conflict to recruit new anti-US. jihadists … … … These jihadists who survive will leave Iraq experienced and focused on acts of urban terrorism. They represent a potential pool of contacts to build transnational terrorist cells, groups and netAgency. works in Saudi Arabia, Jordan and other countries. In other words, what Porter Goss, the Director of the CIA, is saying is that British intelligence warned this mob a couple of years ago. Remember that Iraq at that stage had had negligible contact with al-Qaeda, the mob that killed all those people on September 11, and its offshoot, Jemaah Islamiah, which killed our people in Bali not long after. Iraq, at the stage that we went to war, had virtually no connection with al-Qaedavirtually none. What we have turned Iraq into-and this is the core national security issue at stake in this-is a new recruiting ground, training ground, facilitating pool, swamp, in which the new breed of global terrorists is being trained. This adds to the overall terrorist threat across the world. If we go back again to the extraordinarily arrogant statements by this arrogant minister about his foreign policy responsibilities, I do not know how any person in conscience can walk around and say: ‘Oh, I have just gone over there and created civil war. I have also created a new training ground for a whole bunch of new terrorists. And that is all just tickety-boo; everything is just moving along fine, thanks. There are no real problems.' This affects our security in our own region, our own neighbourhood, our own backyard. Remember the objective was to invade Iraq to reduce the overall terrorist threat. The achievement has been the reverse. Therefore, when the Australian people ask themselves the basic and legitimate question, ‘Is our security as a nation, as a people, better or worse as a consequence of this government's decision to invade Iraq?' any sober answer has to be, ‘It is worse.' Because they are now out there by the thousand trained, exacerbated and excited by the events in Iraq and potentially unleashed on the world. And our authority on this? The Central Intelligence What can we now do to help the Iraqi people, those who have suffered most from this war? First of all, let us just knock on the head some of this bogus, latter-day, post facto humanitarian concern on the part of those opposite. Remember the whole debate about whether they were going to take up their responsibilities as an occupying power in Iraq once the invasion had happened: if you are an occupying power you are responsible, once you invade the country, for the well-being of the civilian population of all 20 million Iraqis. They ran from that at a pace of knots. We reminded them time after time in the public debate and in here that they had formal responsibilities under the Geneva conventions, but they were out in a flash, or at least that is what they asserted-a month or two as an occupying power and flick pass the responsibility to others. This is the mob that now say they have this active role in humanitarian concern. Ask this government this question-and I am sorry Tweedledum, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, is not here today, because we could ask him this question and he could give us an answer. Ms Gambaro interjecting

Speaker: Mr RUDD
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: The member for Griffith will resume his seat. Ms Gambaro- Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I ask the shadow foreign minister to withdraw that comment.

Speaker: Mr RUDD

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS

Speaker: Mr RUDD
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: I have done it twice. Do you want me to do it three times? So here is the key question about the absolute guts of this government's concern for the Iraqi people. Ask this government today-and we have tried to do this through Senate estimateshow many Iraqi civilians have been killed since the invasion; how many Iraqi civilians have been injured since the invasion. I would have thought that, as an occupying power in Iraq, at least until June last year, you would have a passing interest in this because you are the mob running the country. You have got rid of Saddam Hussein-and the Prime Minister has given us his reasons for doing that-you have then actually taken over the government for a period of about 18 months and you are responsible for about 20 million Iraqis, but as of the most recent Senate estimates you were not able to tell us whether there was any reliable calculation of how many people in the civilian population have been killed and injured as a consequence of the invasion. They say now, ‘What about the Iraqi people?' There are things we can do when it comes to the Iraqi people. There are practical things we can do, but this Prime Minister's response is to add this new deployment of almost 500 troops. Despite having been ‘Honest John', loose with the truth for far too long, he said to John Laws: I can definitely say we won't be adding hundreds. I can definitely say we're not going to a capacity to put more regular soldiers on the ground. We just don't have that and I've made that clear to the Americans and the British ... I do not see any weasel word in that. ‘I'John Howard-‘can definitely say we won't be adding hundreds.' That is what he said last April. Of course the Prime Minister now says circumstances have changed. The reasons given are tilting points, tipping points, lipping points, backflip points-you name it, they come up with it. There is a new word every day to explain what they have done. Dutch in, Dutch out; Ukrainians in, Ukrainians out; Bulgarians in, Bulgarians out; Australians up, down-all of it a series of reasons given by this mob, if you listen on any given day, relating to their assertion that circumstances have radically changed. None of them are convincing, but the Prime Minister says, ‘Not to worry, because I haven't misled you.' This is the key point I wish to impress upon the parliament-because it affects all of us, not just in the foreign policy sphere. It is the new prime ministerial doctrine of truththat is, what constitutes lying to the Australian people, what constitutes misleading the Australian people. What John Howard says is, ‘Don't worry; I don't regret it because it was consistent with my state of mind at the time. I like to be inconsistent with my state of mind at the time but it was consistent with my state of mind at the time.' This is worth drilling into just a bit, because it affects all of us. That is, ‘So long as I, the Prime Minister, am convinced that what I, the Prime Minister, said last year was consistent with my state of mind at the time, bob's your uncle. Therefore what I, the Prime Minister, actually say to the parliament and people is not relevant; it is what I think in my mind is consistent with my mind as it was back then.' How do you know what is consistent or inconsistent with have the Prime Minister's mind back then? There is only one person who can tell you. Who's that? The Prime Minister. He is the only person who can actually define whether he has been consistent or inconsistent with his mind when he makes a statement. Anything the Prime Minister actually says is irrelevant, because there is a deeper, hidden, psychological, almost Freudian truth here, which is, ‘What is deeply in my mind at the time?' That is his benchmark for deciding whether you are misleading somebody or not. So this is basically it: ‘I, Louis XIV, the person who runs the show here, do not take questions that are inconvenient. The new standard of truth is this: it is not what I say; it is what I had in my mind at the time.' That is the new Howard doctrine of ministerial accountability in the parliament. There are practical ways in which the Iraqi people can be helped. We on this side of the parliament have argued those for a long time, because the Iraqi people have suffered much in recent years. We argued that we can assist the Iraqi people in their continued efforts against terrorism by assisting in the protection of their oil terminals on the Gulf by the maintenance of HMAS Darwin and those ships which have preceded it and which may follow it. We have argued that we can assist the Iraqi people through enhanced border security. Why? Because there are jihadists coming in through highly porous borders with Jordan, Syria and Saudi Arabia. Based on my last visit to Iraq, one of the areas where acute assistance is needed is in enhancing the border control systems of the Iraqi border security services. We can also assist the UN presence in Iraq itself, and we have made practical proposals on that line. How about a cancer hospital? Oncology services in Baghdad are virtually non-existent. We have a policy which says we should put our shoulder to the wheel and build an oncology hospital. Why not an Australian oncology hospital to service the needs of the Iraqi people? These are practical ways in which we can assist the people of Iraq and help build the peace, but we do not believe you can do that with a Prime Minister advancing a proposition to the country based on a lie. (Time expired)

Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Jagajaga) (3.51 p.m.)Unfortunately, on International Women's Day today, we had the Prime Minister misleading the parliament on a matter that is of utmost importance to working women in particular: the government's promise to introduce a 30 per cent tax rebate on child-care expenses. When the government went to the election last year, they promised that this rebate on child-care expenses would be payable from July this year, 2005. In question time today we had the Prime Minister in his usual triumphant and arrogant manner telling the parliament that he did not know what Labor was on about. Not only is he now up to breaking his promises but also plainly he forgets them. He said in the parliament today that we had got it all wrong and that in fact the payment was being brought forward. Let me inform the Prime Minister about his own promise which is now, of course, yet another broken promise. The Prime Minister has only the Treasurer to thank. Just before Christmas, the Treasurer announced that this promise to allow parents to claim the childcare rebate from July 2005 would not apply any more and that parents would have to wait until July 2006. Parents are going to have to wait another whole year before they get to see any of this tax rebate. The Prime Minister forgets that the promise he made during the election was to make sure that parents could get the benefit of this tax rebate from July 2005. So, Prime Minister, it would be a good idea to tell parents the truth, that this election promise has now been broken and parents will not in fact be able to claim this tax rebate until July 2006. This means that parents are going to have to continue to pay very high child-care fees and that they will not get any relief from those high child-care fees for another yearanother year past the time that this Prime Minister promised before the election. This is a very bitter disappointment to Australian families, and to Australian women in particular on this International Women's Day. It should be a day of celebration, but it is a day when Australian women will have to face up to the fact that on this very important election promise this Prime Minister has yet again broken his promise. Today is a very important day to remember all the other areas where we have a very long way to go indeed. One particular area where this government continues to fall behind is in closing the gap between the average wages of men and women. If we have a look at what has happened to the gap over the time that this government has been in power, we can see that we now have a gap of over $300 a week between men's and women's average total wages. The gap is about $300 a week. The total average wage earned by women is just 65 per cent of male total average weekly earnings. Women's average weekly earnings are now $587.30 while men's average weekly earnings are $898.20. The shocking news for women, particularly for those women on lower wages, is that the gap between men's and women's total average wages grew from $229 a week in 1996 to $310 in 2004. This government has presided over an increase in the gap between men's and women's wages between 1996 and 2004. We have also seen an extraordinary increase in the number of women working in casual jobs. Between August 1996, when this government came in, and August 2003 the number of women in casual work has increased by over 18 per cent. So we now have 1.2 million Australian women working in casual jobs. That is the reality of what this government has done to working women since it came to office. An extraordinary change has taken place in our workplace. Women in workplaces have also been treated like second-class workers under this government. We have seen the pay gap increase, and we have seen more and more women having to take casual jobs where their financial security is at risk. We have women on lower earnings, and the results of that are lower living standards and lower rates of saving and, for women in many circumstances, a chronic and precarious financial outlook. One of the major problems that this government has imposed on Australian women over its time in office is to make their living standards that much worse. It is in the area of child care that we have some of the most serious concerns. We all know that if good quality affordable child care is not available it is just impossible for women to return to work after the birth of their babies. We know how essential it is for women to be able to choose to go back to work, and in circumstances where for their own family's financial well-being some women must work. What are the problems that so many families, so many women, present to us on a daily basis? First and foremost is how hard it is to find a child-care place. Second is how hard it is to afford a child-care place. And, of course, as a result of the Prime Minister's broken promise, the tax rebate that he promised during the election campaign will not be able to be claimed by parents for another year. It is also the case that quality is threatened, primarily because we have an increasingly severe shortage of child-care workers. There has been a lot of discussion in the parliament in the last few days about skills shortages. It does not apply just to the traditional trades; it also applies in this very important area of child care. The Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Patterson, who is responsible for this area, revealed her belief earlier this year. She said in a statement that there were no child-care shortages. I will quote a statement in the Courier-Mail: Federal Minister for Families Kay Patterson said resources had been expanded and her spokesman said demand was being met. Those of you from Queensland, I am sure, would vouch for the fact that that is absolutely not the case. It just flies in the face of reality and it shows how out of touch this government is when it comes to making sure that there is an adequate number of childcare places available. This minister realised the folly of her ways just a couple of days later when she admitted grudgingly that there were ‘a few areas of unmet need', in which case she said the market would solve it. ‘The market will solve it', she blithely wrote in a letter to the editor of the Herald Sun. After this second instalment of the minister's official view on child-care availability I have no doubt that each and every one of you got an avalanche of phone calls. There were various letters to the paper about how it is absolutely necessary for the government to step in and make sure, especially in those areas where it is just not economical for private operators to work-maybe in the area that the member for Gwydir just mentioned; I think the member for Gwydir might have some areas like that in his electorate and I think in Wollongong and in many other parts of Australia there would be some areas like that-where it is just not viable for private operators to work, that child-care centres are available. We do need the government to come in and make sure that child-care centres are available. The cost of child care has skyrocketed under this government. Just two weeks ago a task force on child-care costs-a consortium of leading employers and businesses-put out a press release. Child-care costs, according to them, have increased at 2.2 times the rate of average wage and salary earnings in the period 2002 to 2004. Just in that period we have seen an explosion in child-care costs. This task force also found that more than 37 per cent of the workers they surveyed were likely to leave the work force in the near future because of the cost of care. That is why this broken promise by the Prime Minister is so significant: women are saying they will have to leave the work force because of the extraordinary increase in the cost of care. The government said that they want to introduce a 30 per cent child-care rebate, but only two months after the election-they did not wait very long at all-before the ink was dry, they broke the promise. They said, ‘Sorry, everyone-sorry, parents-you're going to have to wait for another whole year before you get the benefit of this child-care rebate.' Parents have also been left not knowing what they will have to do. Do they have to keep all receipts for two years and then present all of those receipts to the tax office to claim their rebates? Parents have not been told that this is what they will have to do, goodness knows how they are going to find the receipts when it comes to claiming this 30 per cent rebate. The government also broke their promise-once again, just before Christmaswhen they said that the amount of child-care tax rebate that could be claimed was going to be capped. I am sure you all remember that during the election campaign the Prime Minister said that there would not be a cap on the child-care tax rebate, but now they have decided that they spent far too much money in the lead-up to the election and that they are going to have to pull the belt in in relation to child care. The savings that this Treasurer has made as a result of these two broken promises is $344 million. So it is no good the Prime Minister coming into question time and saying, ‘I don't know what you're talking about.' How could it be that the Treasurer is claiming a saving of $344 million if they have not broken those election promises? Either they have the saving because they have broken their promise or they do not have the saving and they have another blowout in their budget figures. In question time today we had an extraordinary example from the Deputy Prime Minister of how to go about making sure you have high-quality child care in your childcare centres. Obviously, the answer is to make sure that you put in your application at the right moment and be the beneficiary, under this regional rorts program, of additional funding for a child-care centre so that you can help with accreditation. Funnily enough, none of us heard about it! None of us knew that you could apply for this money. Funnily enough the regional rorts program extends to the Deputy Prime Minister's electorate and to his child-care centre, but to none of ours! Everybody wants to make sure that their child-care centres are of the highest quality. so All parents want that. Certainly all childcare workers want to make sure that they are delivering child care of the highest standard. One of the major problems with child care is making sure that we have properly qualified childcare workers and that they are properly paid-childcare workers receive very low pay. Very recently we had a decision from the Australian Industrial Relations Commission awarding a significant pay rise to childcare workers in Victoria and the ACT. We certainly hope that when that is implemented it will help. Parents cannot afford to see their fees go through the roof as childcare workers are appropriately paid. That is why, once again, it is so critical that this rebate be paid, and paid on time-and that the Prime Minister is held to his word so that parents ensure that their children go to centres where childcare workers are paid properly but parents are not paying through the nose or having to leave work because they cannot afford child care. Labor had quite a different approach before the last election. We recognised that there was a serious shortage of child-care places. We wanted to add to the number of long day care places, where there are very serious shortages. We also wanted to add to the number of places for after school hours care, where there are significant shortages. I do not think there would be a parent in the country who does not know how hard it is to organise child care, especially during vacations and after school. So on this very important day, International Women's Day, it is time for us to recognise the enormous pressure that this government is putting on parents especially, as a result of its broken promise on child-care. (Time expired)

Speaker: Ms JULIE BISHOP
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I find it rather ironic that this debate, an MPI alleging the failure of the government to deliver for Australian women, should be brought into the House by the federal Labor Party, hot on the heels of a Labor Party factional brawl over the leadership of the party-a brawl which saw Labor members questioning the credentials of a woman for the leadership job, based on her marital and family status. What message does the federal Labor Party send to the women of Australia? In reference to the Labor Party, Susan Ryan, a former minister in the Hawke government, said in an interview on the 7.30 Report: Now we're back in the dark ages, where a woman's marital status and where she has children or not is being used against her by her own colleagues. We can't even blame the media for this; it's her own colleagues that did it. The member for Gellibrand went on in this interview to say, rather plaintively: Let's actually have a debate about the skills and talents that women can offer to politics, rather than try to denigrate people about their personal circumstances. It is little wonder that former Labor member Cheryl Kernot revealed a culture of what she called ‘bullying' in the ALP. It was enough for her to say that she was not suited to the ALP culture and would not return to politics-local, state or federal-unless the culture within the ALP changed radically. So it will obviously be a long time before we see her again. But Labor have double standards on this and on so many other issues in terms of what they say and what they do. For Labor to raise the role of women in Australian society and suggest that their record is something to emulate just exposes their rank hypocrisy. The Labor Party elected as their leader the former member for Werriwa-a man who in his public utterances single-handedly denigrated and demeaned all Australian women when in his crude vernacular he referred to a professional journalist as a ‘dirty whore'. When he spoke so disparagingly about a woman, what did we hear from the men or women of the ALP? Did anyone ask or demand that he apologise as common decency would require? Mr Adams interjecting
