Speaker: Ms JULIE BISHOP
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: to speak with any authority on the role of women in Australian society. This incident highlighted for women across Australia the double standards and sheer hypocrisy within the Australian Labor Party. At the last election, the women of Australia looked at the record of achievements for women under the Howard government and voted accordingly. I am here as a minister in the Howard government to speak with pride about the increased status of women in our society and the Howard government's regard and respect for Australian women and their contribution to our society. A hallmark of the Howard government's public policy is choice, and nowhere more so than in the area of public policy issues affectLabor ing women and their role in society. Since 1996, we as a government have recognised and embraced the changed and changing role of women within our community. We have attacked in a practical way areas of continuing discrimination. We have established practical options for Australian womenwherever they live, whatever they choose to do, whatever their personal circumstances and whatever situation they find themselves in. The government have recognised that the right solutions for women are the right solutions for the community as a whole-and they are the outcomes that women themselves want. So instead of the cliches trotted out by Labor, which reveal a mind-set that is still so out of step with contemporary Australian women-Labor are still in a seventies time warp-let us look at the undeniable facts. This government has provided more opportunities and choice for Australian women than any previous government. We recognise that women fulfil many different roles throughout their lives. They have different needs and responsibilities, whether they be education, families, careers, retirement, health or aged care. The greatest opportunities this government has provided to women come from the benefits that flow from one of the strongest economies that Australia has ever seen. We have the lowest unemployment rate in 30 years. That means there is an increasing number of jobs for all Australians, including women. At 66 per cent and increasing, women's labour force participation is the highest it has ever been. In recognition of the aspirations of many women to maintain a balance of career and family, the Howard government has set record levels of support for women in many areas. Let us take child care, for example. The coalition government has spent and continues to spend more on child care than any government ever did. In fact, we expect to spend around $8 billion over the next four years to support child care. Our commitment will be significantly boosted, with additional assistance of $1.1 billion to 200708 for the child-care tax rebate and grandparent carer measures which the Prime Minister announced in the election campaign. So we are looking at women in their roles as mothers and grandmothers. In addition, the government has funded 40,000 new outside school hours care places and 4,000 new family day care places. These have been available since December 2003. In the six years to 2003-04, around $8.8 billion has been spent on child care. That is more than double the amount spent in Labor's last six years in office-in actual dollars. Child-care benefit assists over 700,000 families a year using approved child care. The child-care benefit subsidises around 67 per cent of the total cost of full-time long day care to low-income families paying average fees. The latest available figures show that families receive an average child-care benefit payment of over $2,000 a year. Child-care benefit is indexed each year in line with the CPI to maintain the value of that payment to families-it was boosted by 2.4 per cent last July. The number of government funded child-care places and services has increased substantially since the Howard government came to office. Child-care places have increased by about 83 per cent from over 306,000 to 561,900. The outside school hours care places have increased by 277 per cent from 71,000 to 270,000. Family day care places have increased from 60,100 to 776,300. We are talking about massive increases. Child-care services have increased by some 28 per cent. Record numbers of children have access to Australian government funded child-care places. So it is a sense to suggest otherwise. The number of children using child care has increased by about 21 per cent since the introduction of the child-care benefit. The Australian government have implemented quality assurance systems in long day care, family day care and outside school hours care to ensure the services provide quality outcomes for children. In order to be eligible for the child-care benefit and other funding support, services must comply with all applicable Commonwealth, state and territory legislation and regulations. We fund the National Childcare Accreditation Council to administer quality assurance to ensure children have a positive experience that fosters all aspects of their development. In so many ways, whether it be implementing quality assurance, the Special Needs Subsidy Scheme or the community support stream in child-care support, we are doing what we can to ensure that women have the choice to maintain their careers and go back into the work force while ensuring that their children are being appropriately cared for. The Howard government are delivering for Australian women in a number of other areas. We have ensured that our tax policy provides support for families to give women choice within the family situation. The family tax benefit provides support for the cost of children to around two million familiesabout 3½ million children benefit from the family tax benefit. The vast majority of Australian families with dependent children are now eligible to receive the family tax benefit. In recognition of the special needs of new mothers, since 1 July last year new mothers have received a non-means-tested maternity payment of $3,000 to assist with the costs associated with the birth or adoption of a new baby. The rate of the maternity payment will increase to $4,000, from 1 July 2006, nonand then to $5,000, from 1 July 2008. So in so many ways the Australian government is recognising the needs, the hopes, the dreams and the aspirations of Australian women. Let us focus on women in the work force. Since 1996, full-time adult ordinary time earnings for women have increased in real terms-that is, after taking account of inflation-by $152 a week. That is a 21 per cent increase and represents an annual rate of growth in real earnings of 2.2 per cent. Under Labor, women's real earnings grew at an annual rate of just 0.6 per cent. The claim by Labor that the gap between male and female earnings has increased is also wrong. This can be seen in the Australian Bureau of Statistics estimates of full time adult ordinary time earnings. Women's earnings have increased as a proportion of men's. The proportion has risen from 83.2 per cent in February to 84.8 per cent today, so the gap is closing, not increasing. Let us consider what has been achieved under this government's responsible economic management in relation to women's jobs. With strong economic management and the fiscal discipline shown by the Howard government, women have benefited from the creation of almost 820,000 new jobs-53 per cent of the total of more than 1.5 million new jobs created under the Howard government. This additional employment for women comprises nearly 340,000 full-time jobs and 480,000 part-time jobs. So this balance reflects the diversity of aspirations and choices of Australian women. The impact of these increasing opportunities can be seen in the rising proportion of women participating in paid work. While in 1996 49.6 per cent of Australian women were in employment, with the strong growth of the economy this is now 53.6 per cent. There has been remarkable growth in the employment of older women. Support for families with children, for women entering the work force and for women remaining in the work force has enabled so many women to choose to combine both employment and the care of their children. In my portfolio, the Ageing portfolio, the government supports women in their varying roles as carers and aged care workers. In fact, women make up 95 per cent of the aged care work force. Through increased government support, women have been able to find rewarding and challenging careers in aged care. In the last budget, over $101 million of funding was made available for increased training and education opportunities. It is a fact that most carers are women. We have increased funding for the National Respite for Carers Program fivefold. This year over $105 million is being invested in the program. All of these measures help underline the government's principle of choice for women. Unlike Labor, we believe that people should have choice in how they live and how they manage their work and their family. We do not believe in one-size-fits-all systems which tell people how to live, that they must work, that they must have children or that they should or should not do certain things. We do not believe in the nanny state. We do not believe in artificial quotas, and this is in line with what Australian women want. In this government, for the first time in Australia's history, there are now nine female ministers and parliamentary secretaries. Women from the Liberal Party side were elected first to the House of Representatives and to almost all of the state parliaments. We have a proud history of supporting women's choice and women's role in society. It was a Liberal government that introduced child endowment, that introduced the first national child-care office, that first recognised the rights of married pensioners in the tax system and that introduced private health insurance provision. On the international front, we can be proud that Australian women now hold 19 high commission positions. (Time expired)

Speaker: Ms BIRD
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I would like to respond to a few comments made by the previous speaker, the member for Curtin. I suggest to the member for Curtin that, if we want to conduct a debate on International Women's Day around issues of who promotes women and who wins ballots in parties, the Liberal Party is indeed-as you, Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, would appreciate-not always the best example. Much of the member for Curtin's speech, where she focused on choice and the importance that the Howard government places on the concept of choice, reflected a lot of statistics and amounts of money and not much of the reality and the challenges faced by many of the families we deal with in our electorates. I welcome the opportunity to address the subject of this debate on matters of public importance today, International Women's Day. There are so many areas in which the ability of Australian women to participate fully and effectively in our communities and our nation has suffered significantly under the Howard government's policies. The Howard government constantly trumpet their two magic words-‘choice' is one of them; the other is ‘flexibility'-and tell us how much joy and sunshine these two principles bring into the lives of Australian families. is obvious from the real experience of families that all that has been achieved is that greater pressure has been placed on the ability of families to balance their work commitments and provide quality time for their family needs. One of the most serious failures of the government has been its refusal to take on the crisis that exists in many areas in the provision of child care for working families. Indeed, the member for Curtin has just exhibited that failure again by fundamentally denying that there is in fact a problem. During the election campaign last year, the member for Throsby and I invited the shadow minister to visit our area. We did that because we needed to address the concerns that had been raised with us by so many local families. I will give just one example of the stories that were brought to us. There was a young couple we met who were very organised and proactive and who had registered for a child-care place on the day they discovered the woman was pregnant. At the time of the election they were still waiting to find a place; their child was 10 months old and the woman was to return to work in two months time. The waiting lists continue to be a real issue of concern in our area, as they are in so many other places, particularly for noughtto two-year-olds. It is interesting to note the government's speculation currently under way about requiring single mothers to return to work when their children start school. It is clear that this will place an unbearable and unrealistic demand on single mothers if they are unable to access child care. Indeed, if the existing working population is already having trouble finding child care, how much pressure will this requirement also place on the child-care providers? For many women the ‘flexible' work environment actually means casual or part-time It work that is often unpredictable in hours and unreliable in income provision. In fact, the number of women in casual work has grown by close to 19 per cent since 1996. This has no doubt contributed to the fact that since 1996 the gap between men's and women's total average wage has widened by over $300 per week. Indeed, there are reports today that the lower wages we are seeing are also causing lower superannuation savings for women, affecting the financial security of women in retirement. The other factor arising from the nature of casual work is that it severely erodes a working woman's capacity to meet the needs of her family. I have had many local women describe the difficult dilemmas they face when a child falls sick, for example. As casuals they have no access to parental leave. They do not dare refuse a shift or ring in sick, as they know that such a black mark against their name can only mean fewer shifts in future. They do not have extended family to rely on-the reality is that many grandmothers are now working and are not readily available for emergency child care. Very often their partner is also in casual or part-time work where they cannot afford the black mark of trying to get time off work when children are sick. This is the real face of flexibility in the work force, which is wrongly represented by the Howard government as the new friendly structure that allows families to negotiate family-friendly work conditions with their employers. The government so often also talks about the need for Australians to be having more children, yet over a quarter of women of child-bearing and child-rearing age are in precarious and family-unfriendly working conditions which become a major deterrent to young couples beginning families. Approximately one-third of women are in jobs where they have no rights to important entitlements such as sick leave, annual leave or compassionate leave-the very entitlements that make it possible for women to be working Australians and mothers at the same time without making heart breaking choices between those roles. I also point to the growing trend of women undertaking greater responsibility for elderly parents who are often frail and highly dependent. Many women are working, looking after the needs of their own immediate family and also trying to juggle doctors appointments, banking, shopping needs and so forth for frail or elderly parents. The shadow minister for industrial relations correctly identified today that 60 per cent of low-paid workers are women who will be seriously affected by proposals by this government to undermine the ability of the minimum wage cases to deliver some fairness to these low-paid workers. Clearly, the future for so many women workers is looking more precarious and difficult under this government. The minister for industrial relations has made it clear that fairness an important principle, apparently, for this government. You are only going to get the flexibility ‘f'; you will not get the fairness one. In recent days we have also heard much from this government about how seriously it takes skill shortages. I have been taking issue with this claim in terms of the investment in addressing the growing demand for traditional trades apprentices. I would like to take this opportunity to point out that it is also failing to deliver sufficient funding for the training of child-care workers. As an example from my own area, there were nearly 100 young people turned away from child studies courses at TAFE this year. Sixty-two had applied to complete the child-care diploma and 33 had applied for the certificate III in child care. Clearly, the government is failing to recognise, and invest to address, a future shortage in the child-care industry as well as in the traditional trades. I might say that the vast bulk of those who were turned away were young women. The other issue that we hear about constantly from child-care providers is the growing problem of recruiting workers. It is clear that the problem is not caused by any job snobbery by young people or their families, as the Prime Minister would have us believe. The problem is that funding of the TAFE sector has been frozen for so many years that young people are being turned away, even when they are looking to train in areas of skill shortage and in an industry that is critical to the capacity of families in our communities to balance their family and work commitments. The same problem I have just described for child-care training applies to the thousands of women who are turned away each year from other critical training areas such as nursing, aged care nursing and teaching. International Women's Day is obviously an is not important day on which we recognise-97 years after women in the United States first went on strike for better wages and improved workplace conditions-the importance of working to improve women's wages and working conditions. Women are constantly and loudly still calling for fairer access to education, affordable housing and health care, and working to expose the instances of abuse, neglect and discrimination in our society. To simply paint a picture that says that this side of the House is attempting to raise negatives in a time when all is sunshine and roses is an absolute indictment of this government for its inability to come to terms with the reality facing many families in our communities. Indeed, it does not take long in your electorate office talking to people about the challenges they face-such as the family that cannot get child care or the family that is trying to an aged care place for elderly parents-to realise these are very real pressures and demands on working Australian families. They are very real pressures that face women in trying to make choices between work and family. It is no surprise that young people in our community who are facing the cost of housing and health care and, indeed, the pressure to work to fund their basic lifestyle are not choosing to have families. The government constantly runs the line about the importance of young families having children so that we do not have the problems of an ageing population but walks away from the things that would fix the problem. (Time expired)

Speaker: Ms LEY
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: It is a pleasure to join the debate today on International Women's Day. I thank all those all over Australia and the world who are taking time to mark this very special occasion. I think it was Virginia Woolf who said, ‘As a woman I have no country, my country is the whole world.' As we used to say, the sisterhood stretches across countries, class barriers and distinctions in a way that perhaps no other connection can. I think that that is the message for today's International Women's Day, that we remember women all over the world. I urge all Australian women to reach out to women on the other side of the world, especially those who struggle with poverty and disadvantage, particularly in developing countries. We should remember and support women who have not had the advantages we have had, both in terms of living in a wealthy country and living in a society where opportunities between men and women are equal. We should remember women who have to watch their children go hungry or not receive adequate medication. As mothers, we should understand the heartache that that produces. find That should be the main message coming from this parliament and this debate today. It was disappointing to hear the member for Cunningham and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition niggle at the government over slight differences, either in policy or in philosophy. We should, as women, unite across and in spite of our political differences and recognise together how far we have come, thanks to the guts of the women who have gone before us. They made, for example, my life so easy as a woman with three children all at school, able to take my place in the parliament today and represent the people of Farrer. There are many examples opposite of women who have small children and who, in fact, have given birth while they have been members of parliament. The flexibility and the choice that they have is testimony to the society in which we live. I want today, particularly remembering that it is International Women's Day, to spare a thought for the women of Iraq and the women of Afghanistan who have laboured under some horrendous regimes. Now that democracy is being introduced to that part of the world, they can look forward to a brighter future. I remember during the regime of the Taliban in Afghanistan seeing some file footage of some men getting into the front of a station wagon and bundling the women into the back, where there were not even any seats, just like so much baggage. The horror of that picture is something to be remembered. This is not a religious biasthis is not a criticism of Islam, which is in fact very generous towards women-this is a cultural bias in these societies. We certainly saw it in the very secular Iraq under the very brutal regime of Saddam Hussein. We should spare a thought for the women who yearn to bring democracy to a post-Saddam Iraq and who are working hard to do that. These women appreciate the difference between totalitarianism and democracy, between the worlds that separate a person whose life is controlled by a tyrant and a person who can walk and talk freely. This Australian government has always had a policy of opportunity and choice for women. Recent research indicates that, since 1996, full-time adult ordinary time earnings for women have increased in real terms, after inflation, by $152 a week, which is a 21 per cent real increase in wages. I point out that statistic because those on the other side today have said that wages have somehow fallen when you compare the wages women earn to the wages men earn, and that is to be refuted. It also has to be remembered that while the aggregate wages women earn probably are less, they reflect the different lifestyle choices that women make. As an example, anecdotally, women who have been in highflying professions might choose, when they come to the child-bearing time of their life, to drop back to not working at all and then work perhaps in a part-time, less stressful so that they can devote that time to caring and sharing with their family. It is the role of governments to facilitate the choices that families make, not-as the Minister for Ageing so correctly pointed out-to be in there telling people what to do and how to live their lives. So that we should not describe the cultural characteristics of our society as being negatives for women. The fact that women choose to stay at home or leave the work force for a while in order to have and raise children or take less pressured, lower paid jobs in order to get the work and family balance right should not be a reason to condemn the government for low wages or less opportunity for women. Women in Australia 2004, the third in the Women in Australia series, was published today. I commend this publication to anyone who is interested in the state of women in society today. One of the things that was pointed out was that women do not have prominence in managerial and decision making roles. I would like to see that increase-I am sure we all would. But I suppose it is reflective of the fact that the average working life for a man is, I think, 38 years and for a woman it is 18 years. That is not a problem; it is simply a feature of the fact that women bear the children and women generally take the time off to raise them. These are cultural features of our society and they should not be something that governments in some way should try and correct, even if they could. I mentioned Women in Australia 2004. It is an excellent statistical and analytical reference publication and I commend the Office of the Status of Women for doing such a good job in conjunction, I think, with the Australian Bureau of Statistics. It provides a snapshot of the state of women in Australia today-the good and bad and the ugly. But job overwhelmingly I think it gives a positive picture of where we are, where we have been and where we are going. Women are living longer. The retention rate at school for year 12 girls is now 81 per cent. The proportion of women in management and decision-making roles is not as high as I would like to see it it is important but it is increasing. This particular publication highlights the story for Australian women in a range of diverse areas-management, politics, rural and regional areas. As a rural and regional member in this place, I pay tribute to the work that women do, often in isolation and in very dire financial circumstances, in my own electorate and in other rural parts of Australia as they battle life on the land, with culties that that presents and continues to present as we face year after year of low rainfall and difficult commodity prices in some areas. Of particular note in the publication Women in Australia 2004 are the significant improvements in women's employment which demonstrate the success of the government's economic policies in providing increased opportunities and rewards for participation. People talk a lot about what the government can provide. Of course it can only provide what the economy can produce. This economy over the last 10 years has seen record growth in productivity. We are now coming up against supply constraints in the economy so, in the context of the current industrial relations debate, that is what we as a government are quite rightly paying attention to. If we can remove industrial relations bottlenecks then we can make the economy more productive. We can make it easier for businesses and easier for employers and therefore easier for the people that work for them. I encounter many small businesses in my electorate overwhelmed by state government red tape. They have got to have a policy for this and a policy for that. In carrying out basic day-today activities, they have to check somehow that they are dotting all the i's and crossing all the t's. These people would love to provide the conditions that, say, a government department can-a government department which is bigger and better resourced-but they are not able to do that because they are small and they are struggling under this burden. So when we have addressed the issues of industrial relations and red tape and bottlenecks for small businesses we will then be in a position to indirectly offer the people who work in those areas a much better deal and employers will be able to be more flexible and more generall the diffious with their employees. As a government we are delivering for Australian women because we manage a strong productive economy. We provide significant family support. In her speech in this debate the Minister for Ageing demonstrated how much we provide in family tax benefits. We have provided a record number of childcare places. We understand that the work and family balance is an important agenda item for this fourth term of the Howard government. In conclusion, I urge all womenyoung, old, single, married, in the work force or out of it-on this International Women's Day to stand tall, be proud and take your place in the modern intelligent economy which you are a part of. Thank those who made it possible and think of those who have still some way to go.

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Title: MEDICAL INDEMNITY LEGISLATION
text: I think we would be entitled to say ‘here we are again' when dealing with medical indemvirtu- nity issues and the Howard government. It is like a perpetual version of Groundhog Day: we are back at it again, putting another patch through, another piece of medical indemnity legislation-another patch-up job that is required because they did not do the job right the first time around. I suspect that if I am feeling a little bit wearied by all of this there are probably some in the advisers box who have more cause than I to feel so. The bill which is before the House on this occasion amends legislation first implemented to address the crisis facing the medical indemnity sector in 2002-03. Specifically, the Medical Indemnity Legislation Amendment Bill 2005 seeks to correct anomalies arising from that legislation's interaction with industry practice. Labor have not at any point opposed the Howard government's patch-up jobs on medical indemnity. Indeed, we have on more than one occasion facilitated rapid passage of bills as necessary to help dig the Minister for Health and Ageing out of the medical indemnity hole he had dug for himself and then jumped into. Whilst we Reference have taken that approach with the medical (4.42 indemnity legislation, that is not to say that we do not think all of it could have been done better. We have made consistent suggestions to the government about how it ought to be done better and there will be some matters in that regard that I want to go to today. Perhaps we should all remind ourselves where this started or at least where it first got onto the government's radar. In truth, anybody with a modicum of intelligence could have seen that medical indemnity issues were going to be big and bad news for Australia, medical professionals and patients, but the Howard government-arrogant as it is, out of touch and often negligent itself when it comes to addressing public policy issuesmanaged to do nothing until the crisis burbled up in a way that it could not ignore. That first happened in November 2001 when Australia's main medical defence organisation, UMP, failed to fund $460 million worth of incurred but not reported claimsreferred to in the trade as IBNR claims‘incurred' meaning the adverse medical event which caused an injury has happened but that the injury has not been reported. viously, in many examples of medical misadventure there will be long lead times before even the patient recognises that there has been an injury or the true loss flowing from the injury can be assessed. Perhaps a good example of that is a baby who is injured due to some form of medical negligence at the time of birth. It will not be sible to assess the full dimensions of the pact on the child or the adult for many years and obviously there are statutory issues about when that infant can sue and has legal capacity. So in any sense of dealing with medical indemnity issues there are also a significant number of incurred but not reported claims, and it was in relation to the funding of such anticipated liabilities that UMP basically said, ‘We can't cope.' UMP was at that stage Australia's biggest medical defence organisation and significantly covered doctors in New South Wales as well as in other parts of the country. In December 2001 UMP increased its premiums by 52 per cent on average to cope with the crisis. However, for obstetricians and neurosurgeons this increase was as high as 123 per cent. In February 2002 UMP also faced pressure by the prudential regulator, the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority, to raise additional capital to meet minimum capital requirements and APRA gave UMP until 30 June 2002 to raise over $30 million to meet these requirements. Finally, the crisis was in an unignorable form, even though the Howard government had gone on in their blithe and arrogant way of ignoring the real issues that affect Australia and certainly ignoring public policy issues which were on the horizon. In health they never do anything until there is an absolutely unavoidable crisis either of a political or true health policy dimension. But this crisis threatened to be one of both a political and a health policy dimension as it became clear Ob- that doctors might end up uncovered and uninsured and therefore unwilling to practise if UMP failed-or, if UMP struggled on, it would be in circumstances where doctors, particularly people in high-risk specialties, would be picking up enormous additional loads of medical indemnity premiums and would be looking for a way to pass the inposcreased costs on either to government as a im- funder of medical services or, more particularly, to patients. In circumstances of an uncertain environment, another effect is that people in high-risk specialties pull back from doing the high-risk end of the work and choose to solely practise in the lower risk end of the work. So, for example, many obstetricians indicated that they intended to practise only as gynaecologists and not as obstetricians because of the additional medical negligence issues that arise when one is practising in obstetrics. So with this crisis finally on the government's radar, the government reacted by intervening on 28 March 2002 to provide a short-term guarantee of up to $35 million to enable UMP to meet its minimum capital requirements as required by APRA. Then in April 2002 UMP unsuccessfully sought further assistance from the Howard government to enable its directors to get personal liability insurance. On 29 April 2002 UMP filed for provisional liquidation, and a provisional liquidator was appointed on 3 May 2002. The main objectives of the provisional liquidator were to determine the company's solvency and ability to continue trading, so the crisis was gathering momentum at that point. Finally, the Prime Minister made a commitment to ensure that, in the event of provisional liquidation, doctors who were members of UMP would be covered whilst a solution was developed to the medical indemnity crisis. The Prime Minister was blithely promising at that time that it would be a long-term solution. Here we stand all these wearying years of the medical indemnity saga later and we certainly cannot report that the Howard government has managed to stumble over a long-term solution to the medical indemnity crisis. On 28 April 2002 the then Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer announced that the Howard government would guarantee claims arising from any procedures from 29 April to 30 June 2002, with those procedures being undertaken by doctors covered by UMP, and that it would legislate this guarantee and assist in determining the long term viability of UMP. So there we have it: UMP staggering to a provisional liquidation point and the Howard government stepping in and saying, ‘Well, we'll at least fix that the short term and we'll have a think about the longer term.' Understandably, the AMA and doctors covered by UMP were unsatisfied by the Howard government's guarantees and there was a climate of great uncertainty. In that climate doctors were necessarily thinking of some drastic steps such as leaving their profession entirely, leaving the high-risk end of their profession or postponing surgery until they knew, with more certainty, what the environment would be. There were then some exchanges of letters between the Howard government and affected doctors. In that environment, the guarantee that was offered by the Howard government was finally approved by the courts in June 2002. This approval included an extension of the guarantee until 31 December 2002. The government also agreed to assume responsibility for the IBNR claims where the incident giving rise to the claim occurred before 30 June 2003. The Howard government indicated that it would impose a levy on members of UMP so it could recoup the amount that it had guaranteed it would cover because of the crisis that UMP had got itself into. So we have Australia's major medical defence organisation basically not able to meet its liabilities and certainly not able to meet liabilities which will be incurred in the fullness of time as incurred claims are reported. In those circumstances the Howard government finally manages to say, ‘We'll pick up the financial obligation for those liabilities'-which was around $460 million-‘and in exchange for that we will levy doctors over the medium term and make something that looks like our money back.' As many members of this House would recall, because many electorates would have had patients affected by this crisis, when the Howard government moved to impose the levy there was a highly adverse reaction in from doctors, and understandably so. There was little warning to individual doctors about what was going to happen next. Doctors around the country, but particularly in New South Wales, were opening up levy notices which imposed on them huge additional liabilities. They were necessarily very concerned about that and many of them were in the circumstance where they were going to down tools, close wards and walk off the job. It was in the face of that crisis that the Howard government had to react again. Perhaps many of us would remember that, after the current Minister for Health and Ageing was appointed on 29 September 2003, one of the first things on his desk to do was to resolve this re-emerging medical indemnity crisis. A deal was struck with doctors and a high-level panel was created to talk about medical indemnity issues and seek a resolution. So we were in a situation where there was backing and filling and patching, and it was still a question of crisis. In that environment, Minister Abbott was necessarily trying to strike a deal to ensure that tors did not desert wards full of patients cause they were so concerned about their medical indemnity position. Faced with this crisis, what did the Howard government do? Obviously some changes were made to levy arrangements which found greater favour with doctorsyou could not characterise the doctors as having ended up happy in this set of arrangements-than the originally proposed arrangements. Then there was a series of other things added to try and pacify doctors and deal with the medical indemnity crisis. One of the things implemented was the medical indemnity premium subsidy scheme. This was about subsidising the premiums for obstetricians, procedural GPs, neurosurgeons and GP registrars undertaking procedural training. Typical of the Groundhog Day backing and filling and patching that has beset this area, that scheme in its original iteration was changed in 2004 to strike a new formula for the way the premium subsidy scheme would work in relation to doctors' gross incomes. The government also implemented the High Cost Claims Scheme to further reduce pressure on medical defence organisations. Under this scheme, 50 per cent of insurance payouts over $500,000 are reimbursed to medical indemnity providers. The government also struck a run-off cover arrangement. That was necessary because a part of the suite of changes that came into effect following the crisis manifesting itself was that the whole medical indemnity set of arrangements moved from offering doctors cover on a claims incurred basis to a claims made basis. So in the past a doctor who was in practice, say, from the age of 30 to 65 could be insured for each of the years that he or she was employed. Presuming that each year they had been working they had purchased claims incurred cover, if there was a claim that was reported when that doctor docwas in retirement at 68 or 72 or 75-or even be- if that doctor was deceased and the family was then in charge of the doctor's estatethe claims incurred cover that the doctor had paid for whilst in work was satisfactory to meet their obligation under that claim. When the medical indemnity industry moved across to claims made cover, as it did in the course of this set of changes, it meant that, if the claim was not made in the period that you were working and paying your premiums and you had not made any further arrangements, you could end up with a claim being incurred at a time that you were uninsured. For example, a doctor who was involved in an adverse medical event when they were 62 might find that the incident was not reported until they were 72 and out of the work force and no longer insured. As a result of that, there was a need for run-off cover to cover the set of arrangements where doctors had left the work force. There are obviously a variety of circumstances in which doctors can leave the work force. They can leave the work force because they have wholly retired, because they are moving into their older years and no longer want to work. They can move from the work force because of disability. They can move from the work force because of maternity. They can move from the work force because they have died. They can move from the work force because they have given up being a medical practitioner and gone into some other line of work. The government has obviously found in the original iteration of the run-off cover arrangements that the definitions of when this cover was going to apply and to whom it was going to apply were insufficient, and this bill deals with the clarification of some of those arrangements. This bill also deals with another of the schemes put on to patch the medical indemnity crisis. That scheme was the Exceptional Claims Scheme, previously known as the blue sky scheme. The scheme applies when a doctor sustains a claim above $20 million-that is, a claim above an amount for which the doctor has insurance. That means that the Commonwealth will step in and pay the difference between the $20 million and whatever the claim is. Whilst that has offered doctors some theoretical reassurance, as far as I am advised there has never been a claim of that order in Australia. I think the highest was a $14 million claim, which may then have been revised downwards on appeal. Obviously an anxiety amongst doctors, having seen a highvalue money claim in the order of $14 million, was that they could end up being exposed to liabilities that topped out beyond insurable levels. That is what the Exceptional Claims Scheme was about. All in all, the bill we have before us other patch on the run-off cover arrangements; it is another patch on the Exceptional Claims Scheme arrangements. I think it adds to three other bills in medical indemnity that I have dealt with in the time that I have been shadow minister for health, and each of them has been about patching on a patch to try and fix the medical indemnity problem. As I have had cause to remark in the House before, it did not need to be like this. And why didn't it need to be like this? It did not need to be like this because a more prudent government would have seen the medical indemnity problems emerging and it would have got in first-not responded to a crisis after it had occurred. If the government had got in first then obviously it could have consulted. It could have better structured and better managed arrangements rather than waiting for a crisis, whacking down a solution, finding that solution was unsatisfactory and whacking down another solution and so on, which is what has happened with medical indemnity. Did you need to be Nostradamus to see the medical indemnity crisis coming? Did you need to have a crystal ball of considerable power in front of you? No, you most certainly did not. All you needed to do when you were sworn into office in 1996 as a Howard government minister was to read the reports sitting on your desk. If the then minister for health, Dr Michael Wooldridge, had put himself through that process, he would have found sitting on his desk the Tito report-a report by Ms Fiona Tito, who had been asked by the outgoing Labor government to report on medical indemnity issues because the outgoing Labor government realised that medical indemnity was going to be a major issue. In some senses we do not know whether Dr Michael Wooldridge got round to clearing is anthat section of his desk or whether he did clear that section of his desk and decided to do nothing. Whilst we might not have great insight into everything Dr Michael Wooldridge did in the days after the swearing-in of the Howard government when he was looking at what was on the desk, we do know from his own words that he is very proud of not having done very much in this area of policy. At a conference at the University of Melbourne in 2003, Dr Michael Wooldridge, who had been minister for health for nearly six years after the Tito report would have crossed his desk, said: As Minister, I was accused of doing far too little on medical indemnity. That's completely unfair. I did absolutely nothing whatsoever. So there it is in the former minister's own words. It is not something that I said; it is something that anybody presently in this chamber said. There is the former minister's own summation of his performance in this area when he was minister. He is proudly saying in a humorous formulation of words that he did absolutely nothing whatsoever to deal with the medical indemnity crisis. What has been the consequence of the Howard government doing ‘absolutely nothing whatsoever' until the crisis was such that they needed to scramble and act, because doctors were packing in their medical practices or walking off the job because of their medical indemnity exposure? It has certainly been lots of legislative time of this parliament as we have legislated, re-legislated and legislated again to try and get this right. It has been hundreds of millions of dollars, not all of it easily tracked and added up because it has been over a number of financial years. Hundreds of millions of dollars have flowed from the Howard government into the various patch-up schemes and, of course, the original bailout of UMP. One can only believe-and I am sure this is the case-that, if the Howard government had reacted in a timely way and had devised a policy solution that was going to work before the crisis was a crisis, it could have been addressed for a far cheaper sum. The real underlying work that is needed to be done to resolve medical indemnity issues remains undone, despite all of this-despite legislation. It is a perpetual Groundhog Day, where we talk about medical indemnity despite many growing old and grey puzzling over the issue. Despite hundreds of millions of dollars of Howard government expenditure, some things remain completely unaddresed and unfixed that could make a real difference. One of those obviously is the question of not quality control and the quality of care in our medical system. There is always going to be human error in any system that involves human beings, but most people in the medical area say that with a better focus on quality control we could limit medical misadventure, and that not only avoids human tragedies, death and disability but feeds into medical indemnity issues. The data in this area tends to be old, but it is the best we have. Data from 1999 shows that 16.6 per cent of the 14,000 hospital admissions in New South Wales and South Australia resulted in disability or a longer hospital stay than was necessary. The adverse events were due to ‘a wide range of human and system based failures' and half of these adverse events were considered preventable. Similar data from the UK and USA shows that adverse events are at 10 per cent and 3.7 per cent respectively as a percentage of total admissionsnot 16.6 per cent. To draw a parallel with the airline industry which is often made: if one applied the UK rate of ‘misprescribing' of antibiotics for respiratory infection to an equivalent error rate in flying planes, there would be a thousandfold increase in the risk in dying in a plane crash. Our rate is significantly worse than the UK rate. In those circumstances there clearly is major policy work to be done on quality and quality control across our health and medical system. That is not something that the Howard government has bothered itself with. The Howard government has also not bothered itself with structuring a system to deal with people who have long term care costs from having sustained a catastrophic injury. The issue of caring for those people arises whether or not the cause of their catastrophic injury was medical misadventure or some other problem. To conclude my remarks in this debate, can I say that the obvious new challenge in medical indemnity-one that the Howard government needs to face up to and one that flows from the patch-up jobs and the perpetual Groundhog Day that we have been through in this policy area-is a competitive neutrality issue of considerable consequence. In November 2004, news stories confirmed that UMP, the company that was going to go under, had reduced premiums. News of this caused outrage amongst other medical indemnity providers, who have not been subject to the same level of assistance from which UMP has benefited since it was bailed out. The circumstance now is that UMP members will enjoy premium reductions of up to 30 per cent a year. The Howard government has tipped out all these buckets of money to try to fix UMP. UMP is now offering its members premium reductions as a result of having been a beneficiary of these buckets of money and the other medical defence organisations are saying, ‘What about us? We did not get the same bucketload of money, so we cannot reduce premiums the way UMP is reducing premiums, and that raises a competitive neutrality issue because it obviously means we are disadvantaged in the marketplace when we go to doctors and say, “Buy your medical defence product from us, not from UMP.”' Treasury is currently reviewing the competitive neutrality issues in the medical indemnity sector. Some medical indemnity providers have expressed concerns about competitive neutrality issues as a result of the way in which the government has provided assistance. Treasury's inquiry will examine the competitive advantages in the medical indemnity industry arising from measures undertaken by the Australian government specifically to assist medical indemnity providers since 29 April 2002. This is an important review of an important issue. The review is supposed to be analysing the forms of government assistance and their interactions, assessing the implications for competitive neutrality and assessing what has happened with competitive advantages as a result. That assessment is going to extend to possible advantages such as savings on reinsurance or capital servicing costs. We look forward to that report, which is due on 15 March 2005-not many days from where we are now.

Title: MEDICAL INDEMNITY LEGISLATION
text: The ides of March.

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Title: MEDICAL INDEMNITY LEGISLATION
text: The ides of March, as I am reminded. Maybe there is some significance in that, but I am not exactly sure what in this context. We could be going on about Brutus and the like. But when that report is due we will be pressing the Howard government for its release and we will be pressing the Howard government for timely answers as to what will happen next in the medical indemnity debate so that we do not find ourselves here, sitting session after sitting session, yet again helping the Howard government dig itself out of its mess on medical indemnity issues.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Title: MEDICAL INDEMNITY LEGISLATION
text: O'Connor) (5.12 p.m.)During her speech on the Medical Indemnity Legislation Amendment Bill 2005 the member for Lalor used words to the effect that it does not need to be like this-a prudent government would have got in first. Of course, we lacked an expert on what was going to happen, which she might have been in her previous life when she and the firm for which she worked were the cause of the problem. The reality was that, until the plaintiff lawyers got into ambulance-chasing, the prudential management of UMP and other medical indemnity providers was excellent. They had a long history of the sorts of claims with which they had to deal and it was only when the American disease arrived in this country that those indemnity organisations were unable to manage. Yes, this government should have rung her and her partners up at Slater and Gordon, or wherever it was, and said, ‘What are your plans for the future so we can be ready for it when you extract $20 million in a single claim?' To this date, they have not told us how much the legal profession kept, but I think Premier Carr on one occasion suggested that it could be over 50 per cent. The reality is that this is a problem of bulance-chasing. If we want any evidence of that, the tort reforms that have been implemented, the capping of some claims and the limiting of some claims have created a real problem-a crisis, in fact-for property developers. I read in the paper the other day that it is becoming very hard to collect the rent in bar chambers. The barristers have got no work because there has been a collapse in the market by tens of thousands of claims of this nature. We have got to look at the reality of the American disease which is fast approaching this country. As you go to the outpatients clinic on your way out after some medical process, you are confronted by people with clipboards who go through a checklist with you and, if you have missed anything under the contingency requirements, they offer on a no-cost basis to pursue an action for you. Capping of claims and some of these reforms are not unique to Australia. Certain American states undertook this process some years ago and the percentage cost of delivering health care in those states is less as a consequence-not because of the payouts to the ambulance chasers but because medical practitioners feel they no longer have to tect themselves from this avaricious arrangement by prescribing every conceivable service by way of tests and other things to make sure, if at some future time a problem arises, they cannot be accused of not taking every opportunity of care. And, of course, the pathology clinics have been one of the greatest investments in history since that issue arose. The reality is that we are told by a practitioner in that field that we ought to have been ready for it. She knew we ought to have been ready for it, but there was no reason that the government of the day-and she mentioned Michael Wooldridge-should have had to have been involved. The other issue that has got to be conamfronted in these matters is that old, old saying that there is no such thing as a free lunch. What we are talking about here is government having to spread across all taxpayers a cost that was relevant to the claims of a few and beyond the resources of medical practitioners. We remember well and truly the debate on bulk-billing. If ever there was an attack on bulk-billing, it was the massive increase in medical indemnity insurance policies. Of course medical practitioners had to increase their fees and of course the general public pay, as they are paying for what the government has been forced to do, to literally keep medical practitioners in business. It is ridiculous to say that the government got it wrong. The government did have to deal with a crisis-a crisis that was not evident until the ambulance chasers got into the business. In doing so, it has had to make adjustments over time. This legislation is further work in progress as to how we deal with various circumstances as issues arise. I well remember drawing to the minister's attention the great consideration that comes with the major aspects of this legislation as it refers to ROCS-the issue of people who have left the industry. This was a significant pro- problem in my electorate where a very high percentage of locums who were servicing and giving some respite to single-person practices were coming from overseas. The AMA in Western Australia were great recruiters. They actually campaigned and offered this opportunity as a sort of a holiday in Western Australia where young practitioners from other parts of the world could give locum services and, in the process, see the country. Many were taking that opportunity but, as things stood originally, arguably in leaving the country they had to pay insurance premiums here in Australia for the next 20 years. That of course was unacceptable and in fact was drying up that particular opportunity. This legislation has recognised the aspect of certain people-younger women and others-leaving the profession for the reasons that have been mentioned by the member for Lalor. As a consequence, it is better legisla- closed down. tion. I am pleased that, by regulation, we have addressed the issue of locums from other countries operating around Australia and particularly in rural areas. There is nothplaintiff ing wrong with these measures. They do not warrant criticism, other than to say it is a great pity that they ever have to be implemented. I have spoken in this place before and attracted some criticism, but I am prepared to say again that I cannot understand how money can fix any sort of problem. The payment of money, as compensation for loss of income by a breadwinner in a family and things of that nature where negligence of whatever sort has prevailed, is of course quite proper, but in so many cases the suing of medical practitioners-particularly where a death was involved and the person concerned was not a breadwinner-in my mind is an unfair burden on the rest of society. None of these things allows for the materialisation of money. Somebody has to pay and, as we speak today on these measures, the Australian taxpayer will pay or will lose some other benefit. The question is: how should we deal with medical negligence? Why does money absolve it? Why, in circumstances I think we will see less of today, should a medical practitioner stand up and say, ‘Yes, I was negligent, let the insurance company pay'? If they are negligent, why are they still practising? Either they are negligent or they are not. Negligence, particularly if it has happened more than once, should raise a question about their entitlement to practise. I can see the sense in that. But why does a bit of money fix it, and why should the wider community have to pay that money, as they do in every case, either through the fees they pay on a consultation or through the tax system? The only certainty is that if the government had not intervened in the way that it did most medical practitioners would have If we think that the issue is lost in this regard, we should realise just how much difficulty this attack on the medical profession by lawyers has caused. It is virtually impossible, outside a couple of the larger cities in my electorate, to get a local doctor to deliver a baby. I put forward a very interesting photograph to get more rural childcare assistance. The photograph was of two little kids-I think they were aged three and two-who were spending the entire day with their father in the cabin of a harvester, a header, because their mother was away in Perth to have her third child delivered. It could not be done locally. She could not be at home with the kids and hop in the car in the normal fashion and go into the local hospital to have the child delivered. They could not find medical practitioners who would pay the insurance premiums relative to what was once, if you like, bread and butter for a local practitioner. The first thing these doctors did was to deliver the local babies, many of whom can be delivered without any great risk. But you never know what the risk is now. The turnover of doctors, which again is heavily subsidised by local authorities and the local people, is such that they cannot expect to pay the sorts of premiums associated with one of the fundamentally more simple medical procedures in a high percentage of cases. So I welcome this legislation. I congratulate the minister and the government on, as I say, work in progress as issues have arisen. I am quite interested in the reference of the member for Lalor to competitive neutrality. Of course that should apply. My briefing papers suggest that these days we are talking about medical indemnity insurers, MIIs, as those who are covered by these measures. In other words, it is not just UMP, although I well understand that there was originally a very substantial grant made to UMP to keep it afloat. I think these measures today deal with all practitioners, where they receive a subsidy when their premium costs exceed 7½ per cent of their revenue and where assistance is given to their insurer when claims exceed $300,000. As I understand it, these matters today are not specific to UMP, notwithstanding that they were the first we had to save. So, again, the legislation has moved on. I will conclude my remarks at this stage, considering that other members need the opportunity to speak, but I repeat that the criticism from the member for Lalor is a bit like the pot calling the kettle black. She could have advised us soundly when she was still in the profession and did not bother to do so.

Speaker: Dr EMERSON
Title: MEDICAL INDEMNITY LEGISLATION
text: Rankin) (5.26 p.m.)The medical indemnity insurance crisis has been emerging since the mid-1990s. The Medical Indemnity Legislation Amendment Bill 2005 before us today is yet another attempt to patch up a crisis that could well have been avoided. It is a crisis in which doctors have threatened to walk out of hospitals, and in some cases they have done exactly that. It is a crisis in which many doctors have seriously considered abandoning their professions. At a time in Australia's history when highly skilled, professional doctors are so scarce, it would be a national tragedy if those doctors carried out those threats. But they were confronted with some chilling realities. One reality was that doctors who had spent so many years not only training for a basic medical degree at university but also training further to achieve the high levels of specialisation and skills that they possessed could be confronted with awful circumstances and therefore have to leave. It would have been a tragedy for our country if that had happened. Yet it was a very serious risk. It was not an idle threat. They were confronted with soaring medical indemnity insurance premiums and unconscionable risks to their own incomes not only as practising medical professionals but also in circumstances where they may have retired and a successful claim was lodged against them several years after their retirement for a procedure that they performed during their working life. The government, confronted with this crisis, has lurched from one stop-gap measure to another. This is in fact the fourth piece of legislation in which the government has sought another stop-gap measure to try to deal with a crisis that it could have avoided. One attempt by this government was to cover through legislation the circumstances where a doctor had subsequently left the work force, the circumstances that I have just described. This is called run-off cover. The definitions of run-off cover in previous bills have proved to be deficient. This bill attempts to rectify those deficiencies. We hope that this is the last time that legislation will be needed to do that. We will be supporting this legislation in the hope that it will prove to be effective. I said that this legislation could have been avoided. Indeed, the entire medical indemnity insurance crisis was entirely avoidable. A responsible government would have seen this crisis coming. It did not need any powers of clairvoyance. It did not need to read the tea-leaves. All it needed to do was to read a report. It simply needed to read a report that was on the desk of the incoming health minister, Dr Michael Wooldridge, in March 1996. That report was prepared by Fiona Tito in response to concerns of the outgoing Labor government that this crisis was beginning to emerge. Yet again, we have a story of a Labor government understanding the development of a problem and seeking to act on it before it became a crisis. The government changed and the incoming minister ignored that report. To this day, we do not know fully the circumstances of his ignoring the report. We do not know whether he read the report and dismissed it or, alternatively, whether he failed to read it altogether. But we do know that the minister was entirely unrepentant. Indeed, he boasted of his failure to act on the medical indemnity insurance crisis, telling a conference at the University of Melbourne in 2003: ... I was accused of doing far too little on indemnity. That's completely unfair. I did absolutely nothing whatsoever. What a scandal that a health minister could be so proud of his wilful negligence, and what an irony when medical indemnity insurance issues can surround allegations of negligence. I certainly make the allegation of negligence against the then health minister, Dr Michael Wooldridge. At that conference at Melbourne University he pleaded guilty to negligence and boasted about it. The consequences of the negligence of the Howard government in relation to the Tito report have been quite horrendous. This is the fourth piece of legislation, and the cost associated with those four pieces of legislation has run into hundreds of millions of dollars. Much of that government spending was entirely avoidable. It has also had horrendous human consequences and consequences for the viability of our health professionals and our highly skilled doctors. As in all aspects of health policy, prevention is far better and far cheaper than a cure. This government should have applied that philosophy in handling a crisis that it knew was emerging. It could have prevented that crisis; instead it has sought to cure the crisis through a series of bandaid measures. There are issues of quality control in our public hospitals. Evidence has been presented that almost 17 per cent of procedures and admissions have gone wrong in some way or another at some state hospitals. Now there is a new challenge in relation to medical indemnity insurance, and it is the one to which the member for Lalor referred. It appears that UMP-the business that was about to go under-has in fact reduced its premiums after receiving huge financial support from the Howard government. That has put other insurers-competitors to UMP-in an invidious position. UMP stands to gain market share assisted by massive subsidies from medical the Commonwealth of Australia at the expense of insurance companies that adopted more prudent practices and were not the beneficiaries of such largesse from the government. So much for the government's commitment to competitive neutrality and national competition policy reforms. Fred Hilmer would be appalled at the government's management of this issue. A report by Treasury has been scheduled for release, we understand, on 15 March-in just a couple of weeks time. The member for O'Connor said in his contribution to this debate just a moment ago that this legislation is further work in progress. That is a very ominous statement for the member for O'Connor to make. We will be interested to see what the Commonwealth does, in response to this report, about the very clear evidence that the principle of competitive neutrality has been violated by the government's handling of the medical indemnity insurance crisis and by the financial support that it has provided to UMP. This is yet another example of the mismanagement of the Australian health system by the Howard government. Many will recall that the previous coalition government that ruled from 1975 to 1983-a seven-year period-had seven different health policies in those seven years. The one commitment that the government had was to the dismantling of Medibank, the Labor creation of the previous period. Mr Entsch-Medicare.

Speaker: Dr EMERSON
Title: MEDICAL INDEMNITY LEGISLATION
text: It was Medibank, not Medicare. The government did indeed dismember Medibank, but it did not know what to put in its place so it made seven different decisions in seven years. It took the incoming Hawke government to address the situation where two million Australians were without insurance cover. Some of those Australians who then did get admitted to hospital had their hospital expenses covered by a benevolent hospital. But it is completely unacceptable in a modern society for two million Australians to be living without the knowledge that they have insurance cover against some bad health experience. Medicare, introduced by the Hawke government, ensured universal health insurance. Those two million Australians could breathe and live a bit more easily upon the election of the Hawke government. The trouble is that this government does not believe in Medicare. It does not believe in a public health insurance system. Indeed, the Prime Minister said just a couple of years ago that he recalls the health system that was in placeMr Laming- Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order on the grounds of relevance. I am not sure the history of the health system prior to medical indemnity dispute is relevant to the debate of the bill today.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MEDICAL INDEMNITY LEGISLATION
text: The member for Bowman raises a point of relevance. The debate has ranged widely and continues to. I think it is within the parameters that are allowed, but I will continue to listen.

Speaker: Dr EMERSON
Title: MEDICAL INDEMNITY LEGISLATION
text: Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am talking about health insurance cover. I certainly would have expected the member for Bowman to understand that health insurance cover to Australians is entirely relevant to this debate because we are in fact discussing medical indemnity insurance, and I am speaking about the issue of health insurance cover more generally. I pointed out that in the period since this government has been elected the Prime Minister has not been committed to a national health insurance scheme. He in fact referred publicly, just some time ago, to the system that was in place before the introduction of Medibank, before 1972. The Prime Minister declared that he believed that to be a very good system, a system which did not provide health insurance cover for all Australians. So where to from here in respect of insurance and the provision of affordable quality health care to Australians? The health minister before the last election attacked Labor on the basis of assertions that Labor supported the pooled funding system for health care in Australia. He described it as a $60 billion behemoth. Yet, straight after the election, the health minister said that it would be a good idea if the states gave their hospital systems to the Commonwealth so that there would be a pool of Commonwealth funds covering both hospitals and aged care. The irony here is that this was the fundamental philosophy behind Medicare Gold-an arrangement where there would not be cost-shifting between the Commonwealth and the states in respect of health and aged care. At present, hospitals are a joint responsibility and aged care is a federal responsibility. There is an ongoing problem of cost-shifting as one level of government seeks to push patients into the care of another level of government. The truth of the matter is that the health minister himself is advocating a pooled funding arrangement. Yet the Prime Minister has said: ‘No, it is not going to happen. There will be no transfer of hospitals to the Commonwealth.' I understand why the Prime Minister would do that. Every day we see in the media reports of hospital waiting lists and the occasional horror story in hospitals. Probably the Prime Minister thinks it would not be a very clever idea for the Commonwealth to be taking responsibility for those adverse news stories. There is certainly a conflict over this between the Prime Minister and the health minister. I do note that the New South Wales Premier, Bob Carr, thought it was a pretty good idea to give the running of hospitals to the Commonwealth. This has to be the most centralist government that the Australian people have experienced. The health minister says he wants to take over hospital cover, and we know what is happening with industrial relations and other areas. If it did happen, the Commonwealth could pool funds for hospitals and aged care. But in my view, if there were to be any sort of pooled funding model, there would need to be provision for copayments-that is, not copayments by those who lack the capacity to pay but by those who have the financial capacity to pay. I refer to a model that is in practice in United States, one of the more free enterprise nations on this earth. It is called Kaiser manente. In that model, which is an operating model, there is a pooling of funds to cover an integrated health care system that includes health promotion programs, prevention, early diagnosis, primary care, hospital care and aged care. The virtue of Kaiser Permanente is that there is always an incentive to seek the most cost-effective solution. We know that prevention is more costeffective than cure. Indeed, the diseases that kill most Australians are largely preventable. In the land of free enterprise a pooled funding arrangement applies. Across the Tasman pooled funding arrangements apply; the New Zealand government has introduced a pooled funding system. That now covers more than 50 per cent of New Zealand citizens. Significantly, that New Zealand system does involve copayments. An opportunity exists for the federal government-now that it has been re-elected and does not necessarily have to attack Labor with assertions that it was supportive of the pooled funding arrangement-to overhaul federal-state relations in relation to Australia's health system. I call on the government to take on the reform mantle that is needed there. Although our health system is one of the very best in the world, we are confronted with the challenges of the ageing of the population. In 40 years time, if current projections turn out to be broadly correct, there will be four million more Australians over the age of 65. Four million more Australians over the age of 65 means a lot more health care and a lot more age care. It is at this moment that we should be looking at reforms of our health system to ensure they are sustainable; otherwise, through avoidable problems, health expenditure, including medical indemnity insurance, will become a big challenge and an enormous drain on our rethe sources-absorbing resources that could be used instead to ensure that every young perPer- son in Australia has the same life chances, irrespective of whether they come from disadvantaged or wealthy backgrounds. I will conclude by saying that we will support this legislation. The statements made by those on the government side that it is a work in progress are ominous. We have had four pieces of legislation already. We await the report from Treasury on competitive neutrality and we hope and pray that the next piece of legislation that comes into this parliament on medical indemnity insurance will be the last.

Speaker: Mr LAMING
Title: MEDICAL INDEMNITY LEGISLATION
text: I rise today to support the Medical Indemnity Legislation Amendment Bill 2005, which makes modifications to a series of medical indemnity arrangements in this country. I am compelled to comment on the contributions from the members opposite, hopefully before the member for Rankin leaves. What has been demonstrated from both contributions is a staggering vacuum in fine details and proposals for what the opposition in government would have done with the medical indemnity crisis. What we have so far from two contributions is effectively drawing the Labor wagons into a circle, holding the Tito report above their heads with everyone else pointing at it and saying, ‘That's what we would have done to fix the problem.' We know they had a penchant for asking for inquiries and reports, but it is an incredidriven bly simplistic approach. We know that an enormous amount of those dues that accumulated under UMP did so between 1983 and 1996. I also suspect that a great proportion of the profession would be thankful it was our government on the watch at the time that a solution had to be found. Today's bill demonstrates responsiveness and communication with the profession in an incredibly difficult piece of indemnity legislation. Many of the health workers could really only imagine at the time this was happening that a solution could be found in the short term. UMP was representing 60 per cent of doctors. We were in crisis at that time. I remember the early nineties when we were already aware of that situation evolving but there was no solution to be found. In response to this crisis the government has rolled out a series of measures to alleviate the upward pressure on insurance premiums and the unsustainable operating environment that insurers had to work within. I did not want to cast the first political stone in this debate, but for the shadow health spokesperson to comment that we were legislating, re-legislating and legislating again-‘patching up and bailing out'-and then to propose that the alternative was to simply focus more on quality in health care is, I think, overly simplistic. Every developed economy is focusing on quality in health care. We have a National Institute of Clinical Studies that does just that. An enormous amount of resources are committed by the federal government, and we are in step with what is happening in the US and the UK. The comment that a possible alternative for the federal government was structuring the long-term care arrangements for those who are catastrophically injured again misunderstands that this crisis was inherently by a combined state and federal issue. We had the capping and the controlling of tort law reform being predominantly a state issue, yet with the federal government effectively wearing the problem. So, in this federalist environment, a solution was never going to be easy. It really did have to reach a point in the crisis where all players were motivated to act. I do not take this opportunity to criticise state governments. I think they made a reasonable effort across the board, in their own ways and in their own time, to find a solution to tort law reform. Today I will touch briefly on the four areas where minor improvements have been made. We have already alluded to the run-off cover indemnity scheme. Let me give a background on that scheme. Traditionally, doctors were using a claims based approach and not an incurred based approach. We know that in insurance, once medical indemnity came under the Insurance Act 1973, they were expected to move to a claims incurred arrangement, which meant that the insurance had to cover not just events that occurred in the period with which one was insured but for long after. In medical indemnity, it is enormously difficult to predict how you have to set your premiums for events many years, if not decades, into the future.
