The agreement was to fall back to a claims based approach, to allow doctors to insure in that way; and for the government to step in-in this case the Commonwealth-with a run-off cover indemnity arrangement, where the government assisted and bore some of the responsibility for that long-term cover. A doctor now with a claims based policy can leave practice and retire safe, knowing that that arrangement is in place. A doctor who is pregnant can leave with maternity leave and take care of her child and, as long as she is not practising, know that that cover is available. Finally, someone who is permanently disabled or suffers a major injury that prevents them from practising can also have that security. The Commonwealth also reimburses the medical indemnity providers for the costs of managing that run-off scheme. But keep in mind that the cost of that scheme is around 8.5 per cent-or, in UMP's case, 9.5 per cent-of the cost of the total amount of the premium. It is a large amount. So what is changing? The eligible run-off claim for doctors who have some but not total cover means that they are now protected. If a doctor has coverage for obstetrics but carries a gynaecological procedure, and down the track finds that they are not covered for that procedure, the run-off cover will protect them, so long as they had some level of insurance and were practising in a prudent manner. In schedule 1, items 17 and 18 prevent double counting of that support payment. That is important so that this run-off scheme payment is not included in the premium outcome upon which that payment is calculated. That provides enormous reassurance to those who are leaving the profession, and particularly those who are retiring. The High Cost Claims Scheme addresses an issue that has been of enormous concern to the medical profession. The solution found by the Commonwealth was that, for all claims over $300,000, the Commonwealth would assist with 50 per cent of the cost. That reduces the cost of insurers finding reinsurance. That exerts a downward pressure on insurance coverage because many of the insurers were having difficulty matching their level of reinsurance-the degree to which they go around and obtain secondary cover-with setting the level of their premium. This scheme will help enormously. It now gives insurers a 12-month waiting period after it is entered on the Federal Register of Legislative Instruments to apply any decrease in that percentage payable for an eligible high-cost claim. It effectively makes it easier for medical insurers. All of these amendments, small as they are, are bringing more closely into alignment the work of medical insurers with community practice. Another change is to the Exceptional Claims Scheme. As I have already said, once medical indemnity fell under the Insurance Act 1973, medical indemnity cover provided to doctors contained a cap of $20 million or $25 million on the amount of damages that may be paid under the policy. Obviously out some doctors realised they would be financially exposed if an award were to be made to a patient in excess of that amount. That put them in a difficult position of potentially being personally liable for certain amounts in a claim made against them. The Commonwealth has again stepped in and assumed liability for 100 per cent of those damages that exceed the doctors' insurance cap. How could an alternative approach from the opposition have made any difference to these issues? I really think it is enormously simplistic, if not a little vacuous, to say, called on Fiona Tito to write a report in the final, dying days of government,' because there was no evidence that any progress was being made while the opposition were in power. It is overly simplistic today not to present a few alternative solutions, if the position are in fact so uncomfortable with some of the items and the legislation that has been developed throughout 2002, 2003 and 2004. Technical changes have also been made to the Medical Indemnity Premium Subsidy Scheme-a scheme which I too hope to be eligible for in my clinical career. Where a doctor's gross medical indemnity costs become so high that they exceed about 7.5 per cent of gross earnings, the Commonwealth again has a scheme so that, in particular, a procedural specialist only pays 20 cents in every dollar of the insurance over and above the 7.5 per cent. That has been enthusiastically welcomed by the profession. Of course, these premium subsidies are paid directly to medical indemnity providers and doctors receive premium subsidies automatically through reduced premiums from the insurer. It should also be noted that the bill today modifies the functioning of this scheme slightly so that it is broadened to all medical indemnity providers and not just the well known medical defence organisations. That is relevant for doctors who are often working in the public system. They too can be covered by this scheme. Premium subsidies also apply to procedural general practitioners. Many of those GPs in rural areas were being forced out of procedural work-general practitioners were putting down the scalpel because the insurance premiums became completely unaffordable. Once again, the solution here was to say, ‘Let's look at a similar GP doing nonprocedural work in the same location who ‘We has the same insurer and we will insure 75 per cent of the difference between the procedural and the non-procedural GPs' insurance premiums.' Again, 10 years ago, when I was a remote and rural general practitioner, a solution like that was unheard of. This has op- been a significant contribution both from the Department of Health and Ageing and from the doctors with whom they have liaised and consulted. Small changes have also been made to the incurred but not reported protocol, which is how one handles claims that are likely to be brought before an insurer but have not yet eventuated into a claim-they have merely been reported by the doctor. There will be changes to that so that insurers will be covered for claims of incidents that are notified to them and the costs that are borne by the insurer, even if they do not progress to a formal claim from an injured patient. There was a comment today from a leading medical practitioner in Queensland who said that we had a lot to be grateful for in this legislation and that by and large the issue of medical indemnity had been sorted out. A comment like that from the medical profession was almost inconceivable four years ago. I know from what has happened in Redlands Hospital that the issue of medical indemnity has all but disappeared from the common rooms and coffee rooms of hospitals. Morale is higher in Redlands, in particular, which is a fine hospital. Redlands is waiting for an emergency department upgrade promised by the state government, which is coming soon. What are not appearing are the nine renal chairs that allow dialysis to be done in our area. That puts an enormous burden on the nearby Princess Alexandra Hospital and obviously upon a lot of annoyed renal patients. The topic of indemnity has almost disappeared from hospitals and from practices around the country. It was once said-I am not quite sure by whom-that, like God's infinite mercy, professionals should never really rely on government when it comes to sorting out indemnity issues, except as a last resort. That is exactly what happened in 2002. I was flying across the Gulf of Carpentaria when it happened, I recall. At that time there were no clearly understood solutions to the problem. It almost had to reach this stage in negotiation before all of the groups involved, including the state governments, could be brought to the table to have a summit. That is exactly what this government organised. I am thankful that that happened. It happened under the watch of a government that was able, willing and keen to strike a solution for the benefit of the profession. Announcements were made in December 2003, and all of those measures have now been implemented today. Consultation with doctors, of course, remains ongoing. It will have to-there will be further finessing. Again, it is overly simplistic to say that this has been a botched job, a patch job or a bailing out, because there was really no other way, and I am yet to hear from the opposition that there was any other way of handling this issue. I am glad that the elements of the bill today will be working as they were intended. The small changes, many of them technical, some of them quite detailed, do just that. I congratulate not just the current Minister for Health and Ageing but also his predecessor, Minister Kay Patterson-and also Minister Helen Coonan for her work as Assistant Treasurer-on the work they have done in helping medical indemnity insurers, because they know, as we do, that by helping them we help doctors, which, in turn, helps patients.

Speaker: Mrs HULL
Title: MEDICAL INDEMNITY LEGISLATION
text: Riverina) (6.00 p.m.)Again, it is a pleasure to rise in the House add my comments to the debate on the Medical Indemnity Legislation Amendment Bill 2005. This has been a long-running and sometimes terribly volatile issue in my electorate. Some 18 months before UMP collapsed, I had visits from my obstetrician, Dr John Curry, who came to tell me that there had been calls on the profession. He felt that there was going to be a disaster with UMP and needed to raise my awareness of this issue, which he did. We travelled to Canberra on numerous occasions and addressed backbenchers and committee meetings and pulled together meetings of backbenchers. Specifically, Dr Curry highlighted the issues he felt were going to happen, certainly with UMP. He felt that there was no money in the system and that the call was significant on the profession. He said that, unless somebody stepped in and did some work on tort law reform in the states, particularly in obstetrics areas, looked at the 21-year statute of limitations and at the way in which certain cases were playing out whereby compensation was being paid in the extreme, this was going to be a major issue that we would face as a nation. We did a lot of work on this matter. Many of my specialists came on board and explained that they thought there was a problem. Then we had a problem because there was no indemnity cover in the state hospital system, so all my specialists in the Riverina decided not to offer their operating services. I was involved at the time in the process of trying to resolve the issue with New South Wales Minister Craig Knowles. Finally, common sense prevailed and the state government, to their great credit-and it is not often that I give credit to the state government-decided to pick up the indemnity in the public hospital systems for medical practitioners. It was very much appreciated by me and all of my medical specialists, GPs to and others, because it certainly resolved the issue of getting cover in the public system. It stopped a mass exodus from the public system to the private system whereby we would have had an enormous gap in services that could and should be provided by the state hospital system. The issue was resolved at the eleventh hour on Christmas Eve. It was pretty significant and pretty hair-raising to think that, after the new year, no specialist services, operating services and visiting medical officer-VMO-services would be available in the state hospital system in my electorate. We then moved to the UMP crisis-and what a crisis it was! It saw, very quickly, mass exodus of specialists who had decided to retire, or who were thinking of retiring, three to five years. They were insecure about what was going to happen in the future and not quite sure what was going to happen in their family lives and with the assets they had built up over a long period. We put in a lot of work and a lot of effort. Various crafts assisted me in trying to resolve this issue. One of my good general surgeons, Henry Hicks, was absolutely sensational. He, along with Dr Gerard Carroll, a heart physician in Wagga Wagga, and Dr John Curry, an obstetrician, assisted me in resolving this issue, particularly in my electorate. It seemed as though this matter was just going to escalate-and it did. Obstetricians have one private outlet in the Riverina-that is, Calvary Hospital-and they decided to remove their services from that hospital. We have about 600 or 700 deliveries per annum in the private hospital and about 700 to 800 in the Wagga Wagga Base Hospital. It was obvious that the base hospital was not set up to take all the deliveries from right across the Riverina into their sector, and we had a crisis. Two thousand members of the community-mums and dads with prams and babies-marched up the streets of Wagga Wagga to demonstrate that they needed this facility at Calvary Maternity Hospital and that we in the government desperately needed to resolve the issue. There was a significant amount of discussion and negotiation, as a former speaker has said, by ministers and the Assistant Treasurer at the time, and we ended up resolving the problem in the short term. We then introduced a levy system and, of course, some anomalies started to develop in that system. We saw new entrants coming in. One of the surgeons in my electorate, Dr David Littlejohn, was a new entrant in the system, and it seemed that he was going to the have to pick up the tail and pay for the mistakes of people before him. That, of course, in needed resolving. This issue has been a moving feast for ministers, because every day there was a new and extremely significant issue that they had to deal with and try to resolve. The Australian public were beside themselves because they thought there was every chance that they were going to lose their services. It certainly did have a major impact, particularly on obstetrics. We saw many of the obstetricians in my electorate move out of obstetrics entirely and into the field of gynaecology to reduce their premiums. This left a great shortfall in obstetrics services, not just in my electorate but right across Australia. In what I think is its absolutely best performance to date, in an effort to underpin services right across Australia, the government has had to deal with a moving feast of variable issues that were surrounding things that governments had not previously been involved in. It did not just involve obstetricians, orthopaedics or surgeons; it also involved anaesthetists. A host of different specialists had been impacted upon by the very difficult circumstances with United Medical Protection. So I congratulate the government on all the processes it undertook to ensure that everybody's interests were served-not just those of specialists, GPs, obstetricians and surgeons, but also those of all Australians. Some positives have grown out of this. There are some positive advantages in what has happened. After we had the march in 2000 up the streets of Wagga Wagga, we developed a new program called the rural obstetrics training network. I sat down and thought that if the UMP issue was going to cause such a crisis in my region, what were we going to do to stop people from being discouraged from entering obstetrics because of the 21-year statute of limitations? I decided to work with a group of specialists to determine how we could deliver obstetric services into the future in rural and regional areas. From that came the birth of the rural obstetrics training network and we now have a very good pilot project operating out of Wagga Wagga which is looking at how we deliver obstetric services for rural and regional people into the future. It utilises wives and a whole host of different mechanisms that need to come into play in before and after care in obstetrics services. I am very proud of this. Dr Ian Stewart is a practising obstetrician and gynaecologist. He has now reduced his hours to part-time gynaecology in order to take on the directorship of the rural obstetrics training network. In my opinion, nobody has more experience in the needs of rural obstetrics than Dr Ian Stewart, and he has been prepared to forgo his own monetary benefit to ensure that he can put together a valuable project that can be applied anywhere in Australia. The project will ensure that we are best utilising the service of midwives and it will encompass regional universities such as Charles Sturt University, which has a magnificent nursing and midwifery course. It will put a process together to provide a different form of delivery of service for those people who are removed from many of the major areas of delivery. At one stage, we thought we would have to airlift mums to Sydney or to a metropolitan hospital just to have simple, straightforward procedural deliveries, which would certainly not have been a good use of taxpayers' money. As I said, this is a long-running issue that I have been absolutely involved with, well and truly before the problems with UMP, simply because of the understanding that the specialists that work in my area had to be involved as part of the solution and not just as part of the problem. I am very fortunate to have each and every one of the specialists in my area. We have recruited specialist services due to all of these guys putting in together and utilising their own money, their own time and their own travel to get other specialist services into the Riverina. The average age of specialists in the Riverina now is between 40 and 45, which is absolutely sensational. We have one of the best medical midwork forces in specialty services. We are certainly lacking in some areas but the Riverina is starting to be well supplied with specialist services. The government has assisted the Riverina in many, many ways to ensure that specialists remain committed and have the incentive to move forward and to be able to continue to offer these services into the future. In other positive news in my region, according to a recent newspaper article Cootamundra is also benefiting from an increase in professionals who are providing obstetric and maternity care. This is fantastic because, while most regions are seeing a reduction in these services, I am starting see a significant increase, mainly due to the commitment of the existing specialists there. The article in the Cootamundra Herald on 2 March 2005 states that two new midwives, and a new general practitioner with an interest in obstetrics, have moved into the town of Cootamundra. The report says: ‘We have been short of midwives for a long time and Cootamundra is very lucky. Not only do we have the two new midwives but we have a new doctor in Dr Scholz.' Scholz is a significant name because Granny Scholz delivered Sir Donald Bradman in Cootamundra and now Dr Scholz is there providing obstetric services. Now that I have finished making conversation in the House, I am pleased to congratulate the government on the very fine effort that they have put in and in particular congratulate the Minister for Health and Ageing on the services that he has secured for rural and regional Australia.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: MEDICAL INDEMNITY LEGISLATION
text: I am very pleased to sum up the second reading debate on the Medical Indemnity Legislation Amendment Bill 2005 and I would like to thank all members who have taken part. I would particularly like to thank the member for Riverina for a very interesting tour de horizon of the medical services available in her electorate. I am not entirely unfamiliar with them, having visited a couple of times and also having pedalled through a large slab of her electorate in company with, amongst others, the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads. It is good to see the medical services of the Riverina appropriately eulogised in this place by a very hard working local member. Eighteen months ago there was a genuine crisis in our health system. A large number of visiting medical officers were resigning their public hospital positions because they believed that medical indemnity premium increases were the last straw. They believed that they were being hit with unconscionable burdens as a result of changes to the tort ture, particularly in New South Wales but also in Queensland and in other states. As a result the government established the Medical Indemnity Policy Review Panel comprising a series of distinguished leaders of the medical profession, along with John Phillips, former Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank; Nancy Milne, the insurance partner at Clayton Utz; and the then Minister for Revenue, Senator Coonan and me as co-chairs. But the key people on this review panel were Dr Bill Glasson, the President of the AMA; Dr Andrew Pesce, the insurance expert on the AMA; Dr Sue Page, President of the RuI ral Doctors Association of Australia, and Professor Don Sheldon, Chairman of the Council of Procedural Specialists. That committee spent a very intensive six to eight weeks looking at the problem and coming up with a series of recommendations which were ultimately accepted, almost in total, by the government just before Christmas in 2003-and which, I am pleased to say, have brought stability to this sector since. I do not say that it is a perfect system and I do not say that it will not be in need of further work in the future, but certainly the crisis has passed. The medical specialists rescinded their resignations, our hospitals began to work normally again and the Damoclean sword hanging over them was withdrawn. This was very good news for the people of Australia but it was particularly good news for the standing and public respect of the medical profession. Every one of us in this place owes a great deal to the medical profession. None of us enjoys perfect health all the time, and invariably when ill health strikes it is the medical profession which takes the lead role in restoring us to health. While many doctors earn large incomes, the vast majority of them carry very heavy cul- responsibilities, work very long hours and earn comparatively modest rewards for the training, dedication and time that they bring to their jobs. It is right that we as a society do not impose unduly heavy burdens on them. Thanks to the Medical Indemnity Subsidy Scheme, finalised by the government as a result of the work of the review panel, doctors who face very high premium costs will have 80 per cent of those premium costsabove 7½ per cent of gross private medical income-met by the government. That is the essence of the scheme put in place by this government to meet the crisis, but there are other important elements: the ‘blue sky scheme' to cover doctors who face claims in excess of $20 million; the High Cost Claims Scheme to cover doctors who faced claims in excess of $300,000; and the very important retirement Run-off Cover Scheme to cover doctors who had retired from practice but who still faced the possibility of claims as a result of the long tails on these sorts of actions. As I said, it has not been an absolutely perfect set of arrangements. Obviously it has cost the taxpayers of Australia heavily. The package put in place after the review panel did its work cost an additional $200 million over the forward estimates period on top of about $350 million that had previously been invested by the government in medical indemnity insurance premium support. But the package has worked well and this legislation is designed to clear up technical difficulties which have arisen in the operation of the scheme. In particular, we have tried to ensure that the legislation precisely matches the intent of the government back in December 2003 and that it precisely matches the practical operation of insurance schemes of this type. The legislation is highly complex and technical but it has been drawn up in the closest possible consultation with the insurance sector and expert members of the medical profession. I know that the legislation has the support of the medical profession and the medical indemnity insurance sector. I know that it is in the best interests of patients that we should pass this bill and I particularly thank the opposition for being as constructive as they have been on this whole issue. Before closing, I should also thank the public servants of my department, who have toiled mightily over this issue for the last two or three years. We tend to take the Public Service for granted-and certainly the general public often talk dismissively of Canberra as if it were a paradise of overpaid and underworked public servants and people such as ourselves-but the fact is that the Public Service of Australia always get the job done. Sometimes, as our experience grows, what they do needs to be finetuned and further improved, but they always get the job done. In my experience as Minister for Health and Ageing there has been no finer illustration of the Public Service at its best than the work that the Department of Health and Ageing did to resolve this very acute, very pressing and very serious problem. So I thank and congratulate them on behalf of the government and the people of Australia. I particularly single out Charles Maskell-Knight, who is in the advisers' box this evening and led the team which did such a good job. Thank you very much indeed. Question agreed to. Bill read a second time. Message from the Governor General recommending appropriation announced. Third Reading

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: MEDICAL INDEMNITY LEGISLATION
text: by leave I move: That this bill be now read a third time. Question agreed to. Bill read a third time. NA AMENDMENT BILL 2005 Second Reading Debate resumed from 16 February, on motion by Mr Truss: That this bill be now read a second time. Mr GAVAN O'CONNOR (Corio) (6.24 p.m.)-The opposition will support the Farm Household Support Amendment Bill 2005 through this parliament. The bill seeks to reinforce the structural adjustment focus of the Farm Help program by tightening the definition of ‘full-time' farmer and by providing the ongoing monitoring of those who have accessed the re-establishment grant, to ensure that they do not go back into farming. In June 2004, some eight months ago, I debated legislation to extend the Farm Help program to 30 June 2008. The opposition has been broadly supportive of the thrust of this element of the Agriculture Advancing Australia package. This program forms part of the government's Agriculture Advancing Australia package and is aimed at supporting the ongoing process of structural adjustment in the rural sector. However, if the number of farms accessing this program is supposed to be an indication of the success or otherwise of the program, then the statistics would seem to indicate that it has been a failure. Farm organisations regard this program as largely having failed to meet its objectives, and, on the government's own stated objectives, it has failed badly. On that basis, I move: That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: “whilst not declining to give reading, the House condemns the Government for the failure of Farm Help and other programs to deliver appropriate structural adjustment assistance where it is needed in the farm sector”. Farm Help has been operating since December 1997 to facilitate adjustment by providing assistance to people on farms in severe financial difficulty. Program components include up to 12 months of income support at the newstart allowance rate, up to $5,500 in professional advice and training, the development of an activity plan customised to each farm family situation and a re-establishment grant of up to $50,000 for those who decide to exit farming. The Farm Help program was renewed in the 2004-05 budget for a further four years and will conclude on 30 June 2007. The farm exit provisions of this program have been the centrepiece of the government's structural adjustment efforts in the farm sector. But in most years the program has been significantly underspent. While the amendments proposed represent an improvement on the current situation, particularly in terms of accountability for assistance received, they will do little to encourage an increasing number of marginal farmers to exit farming. The main elements of this bill are that it will amend the definition of a farmer as ‘a person who has a right or an interest in land used for the purposes of a farm enterprise' and that it will define a ‘full-time' farmer, for the purposes of the Farm Help provisions of the bill, as a person who, for a continuous period of at least two years immediately before they apply for entry to the Farm Help program, is a farmer, has derived more than 50 per cent of his or her gross income from the farm enterprise, has contributed more than 50 per cent of his or her capital to the farm enterprise and has spent more than 50 per cent of his or her working hours on the the bill a second farm enterprise. The bill will also provide a greater degree of flexibility in administration. For example, a person may be unable to satisfy the income test because, during the two-year period, the enterprise has experienced flood, drought, bushfire or some other natural disaster; an unforeseen extreme variation in seasonal norms; a market collapse; or serious illness or disability. Accordingly, a person is considered to be a full-time farmer if they can demonstrate that they meet these circumstances and other qualification criteria. Of course, there is another provision of the bill to enable ongoing communication with Farm Help re-establishment grant recipients. This provision basically allows for the tracking by Centrelink of people who have received assistance under these provisions. One has to ask why these matters have not been adequately addressed by the government before this time. It is quite extraordinary that here we are some seven years after the introduction of the scheme, and the government is still grappling with the definition of a farmer and a full-time farmer. I think it demonstrates the sort of tardiness in the preparation of legislation and the administration of schemes that is typical of a government in terminal decay, as is this one. The government introduced the scheme in December 1997. One has to ask where the minister has been since that time in tightening up the provisions of this particular legislation. At least, I suppose, some seven years down the line we are finally getting some certainty into these definitions. Of course, in doing so, the minister simply demonstrates once again his incompetence in this portfolio. The process of structural adjustment in farming has produced mammoth changes in our agricultural sector. Of course, this is what this particular legislation is designed to address. I have, on more than one occasion in this place, referred to the impact that it had on my own farming family, who farmed a small, mixed dairy farm in the western district of Victoria some four decades ago. That process has produced quite profound social changes in rural communities, often with great pain to families who were farming and who, in a historical sense, have farmed as a lifestyle choice as well as a means of earning a living and supporting a family. The process of structural adjustment has been propelled by a range of factors. In Australian agriculture in recent decades, we have witnessed quite consistent growth in the annual productivity of the sector of between one and two per cent. This has been driven by massive investments in technology on the farm, land productivity improvements, huge strides in plant and animal genetics, the decisions of government to remove the regulatory framework under which industries have operated for long periods of time, an expansion of market opportunities, the upskilling of farmers, the introduction of new management and information systems, some improvements in essential infrastructure and, of course, significant gains from a concerted research and development effort in the sector. Together these have driven the creation of new opportunities and new efficiencies in Australian agriculture. They have also, however, contributed to the massive structural adjustment in the sector that has occurred in recent decades. Other influences have contributed to the process as well. Climatic changes, such as the recent drought, have put enormous pressure on the financial viability of many farm enterprises in affected areas, with corresponding pressures on businesses and local communities. The overall issue of climate change and the potential impact it might have on the farm sector are the subject of considerable debate in the general commuhas nity and in farming circles today. That certainly was not a debate that was taking place with any intensity some five years ago, but of course it is upfront and centre in the considerations of farmers and their leaders today. I have taken the view in that debate that the sector must look to innovative opportunities and not simply wallow in the negative aspects about the extent of the sector's contribution to the problem. The reality is that managing this problem and related problems, such as the increased incidence of pests and disease, may well be beyond the management skills of many farmers in some prone areas, forcing the pace of structural adjustment even faster. Similarly, the changing nature of consumer preferences in how they buy and consume the output of the sector has dictated changes in the structure and will do so in the future. Consumers can be very fickle indeed in changing their preferences and having their needs and wants met, and sometimes the resources in agriculture are not flexible. Some industries, such as the stone fruit industry, require significant time frames for adjustments to occur and significant investments to meet new consumer demands, so the process of adjustment for many in the farm sector is a difficult one indeed. Likewise, the changing nature of the domestic and the international marketplace and the dominance of huge retailers are putting significant pressures back on farm. These changes are eloquently outlined by Mick Keogh, the Executive Director of the Australian Farm Institute, in a perceptive article in the February 2005 edition of the Farm Policy Journal, entitled ‘The industrialisation of Australian farming'. He refers to the fact that this process of industrialisation appears to be rapidly developing in agriculture. I forgot to bring that article with me today to quote from it in this debate, and I regret that because it is an excellent article. It is very ceptive and very detailed, and I think it makes very important reading not only for farmers but for those in agribusiness and those who have an interest in the process of structural change in the sector. Farm structures have adapted to accommodate these new arrangements. Keogh refers to the emergence of large-scale corporate farms. They have emerged and they are highly integrated into current food marketing systems, with direct contractual arrangements between those large corporate enterprises and large retailers that literally bypass traditional marketing systems. Keogh provides a very comprehensive analysis of the nature of these new marketing arrangements and the impact that they are having on the contractual relationships in the agricultural sector, on intellectual property rights and on patterns of trade. In the face of these particular changes I think Australian agriculture has shown remarkable resilience, but there are even more economic changes bearing down upon the sector as we speak. We are going to see further structural adjustment in this sector as a result of the rising interest rates under the Howard government. It is now a matter for the public record that the Prime Minister and the Howard government have deceived farmers, as they deceived other Australian households and businesses before the last election, on the matter of interest rate rises in the future. The Prime Minister is in his usual pattern of doublespeak on this matter in what I consider to be a pathetic defence of his deception. The economic framework has direct relevance to the pace of structural adjustment in the rural sector, and it is that issue of structural adjustment that is the focus of this particular piece of legislation before the House. Before the last election the Prime Minister led farmers to believe that interest rates perwould not rise. The Reserve Bank has recently increased them by 0.25 basis points, and it would appear there are more rises in the pipeline. What is the impact of this on the farm sector? I refer to a press release by the National Farmers Federation on 2 March 2005 where they have analysed the quantum of the impact that that is likely to have. Mr Charles Burke, the Farm Business and Economics Committee chair, had this to say: Around 10 per cent of total farm cash costs go towards servicing average debt levels of about $370,000 per farm. This means that today's move by the RBA will cost Australian farmers another $120 million a year and squeeze margins which are already under pressure from high exchange rates and high fuel costs. Here we have the triple whammy: the rise in interest rates, courtesy of the Howard government, which is adding $120 million to farm costs; a squeeze on margins which are already under pressure from a high exchange rate, which in part is due to the policies of the Howard government; and, of course, high fuel costs, which in part are a result of this government's involvement in the Iraq conflict. So in a whole raft of economic policy areas we have a direct pressure on farm costs and on farm adjustment-which is the subject of this particular bill-as a result of the policies of the Howard government. Mr Burke went a little further. He said: The rate rise also comes on top of one of Australia's worse trade performances on record. The Current Account Deficit has hit $15.2 billion or 6.5 per cent of GDP. I think that is perhaps a little bit on the light side. But it is the impact of our trade performance on exchange rates and on rural exporters that he goes on to analyse. He says: Higher interest rates will push the exchange rate higher, damaging exporters and fuelling more imports. He further concludes: We need to boost exports to address the record current account which means that ideally, our interest rates should be falling relative to our jor trading partners. As we know, Australian interest rates are at decidedly higher levels than those of our trading partners. The high interest rate regime in Australia is fuelling the pressure on the exchange rate and this, in turn, is damaging farmers as significant exporters in this country. The foreign account relies very heavily on the input of the farm sector as far as earning national income goes in the international marketplace. So here we have, as a result of the Howard government's policies, a double whammy coming to farmers. Courtesy of the Howard government's economic policies, we have a rise in interest rates which is adding to farm costs to the tune of $120 million on this occasion-and that is not taking into account the massive increase in costs that has occurred as a result of interest rate rises that had already occurred courtesy of this government. I would say that, just as a rough rule of thumb, the interest rate rises courtesy of the Howard government have added some half a billion dollars or more to farm costs, and that is not an insignificant amount. And then, of course, as this feeds into the higher exchange rate, farmers as exporters are penalised. Their income is reduced from their exports into the international marketplace. So there is a squeeze on their incomes, their costs increase and their financial viability is further threatened. I am very interested in the interest rate debate because we know that the Prime Minister is apt to get up in this parliament and talk about high interest rates under Labor. But of course he conveniently forgets that when he was Treasurer of this country not only did he leave us with a deficit, which in current dollars would be the equivalent of $30 billion, but he presided over interest rates to businesses of 15.8 per cent. And the Prime Minister has the gall to get up in this parliament maand criticise the Labor Party for high interest rates. One thing that we did do, something which really assisted farmers to cope with this issue of structural adjustment, was break the back of Liberal inflation in this country-the double-digit inflation that prevailed when the Liberal Party was in power under the Prime Minister's stewardship as Treasurer. We broke the back of Liberal inflation. We set the basis for the low interest rate regime that this country now enjoys. So the issue of the total economic performance of the country is very important to this process of structural adjustment and it is very important to the issues we are debating here today in this legislation. I go to the statistics that relate to the Farm Help Re-establishment Grants Scheme. We have seen that the number of exits under the legislation has not been of any substance since the year 2000. For example, in 2000-01 there were 182 re-establishment grants. In the next two financial years, 2001-02 and 2002-03, there were 161 in each of those years. It further declined in 2003-04 to 102 re-establishment grants. We can go to various industry reform packages that the government has introduced since it has been in office. If we look at the Sugar Industry Reform Program, for which funding of some $94 million was made available over the years 2004-05 to 2006-07 for re-establishment assistance, we find that, as at 4 March 2005, 82 growers had accessed re-establishment grants under that industry reform package for 2004-05. That is not a lot, given the noises that the government was making about the need to encourage many sugar farmers to exit the industry because of the economic challenges it faced. With the Pork Producers Exit Program, the government and the minister's estimated target was 140 producers, but only 74 have received pork producer exit grants. We see a similar situation occurring in the Dairy Exit Program where Centrelink have advised that there have been approximately 138 grants awarded under that program. So it is hardly a massive structural adjustment tool. It is no wonder that many in the farm sector have been very critical of the government for its administration of this particular piece of legislation. If we go to the National Farmers Federation submission to the review of Agriculture Advancing Australia, we see that very little has been done by the government to address their concerns in this matter. For example, the National Farmers submission said: Farmhelp and similar exit programs should provide incentives for farmers considering retirement or industry exit to link with young individuals pursuing industry entry, therefore facilitating and accelerating the generational transfer of viable farm businesses; Nothing has been done on that particular request. The submission also said: The Retraining Grant and the entire Professional Support components of Farmhelp should be available to farmers prior to them making their final decision on exiting the industry (through taking the Re-establishment Grant), therefore providing additional confidence and guidance to farmers in considering their future options; This is one that has been done. But then, further down in the submission, National Farmers suggested that Farm Help: Introduce flexible measures to allow support to continue beyond the first 12-months in circumstances where farm exit maybe inadvertently delayed (ie: problems in selling property etc) or where an assessment of farm viability may take longer than this period; On that sensible suggestion, nothing has been done. The National Farmers also state: In lieu of a bank statement documenting a farmer's credit rating, allow Rural Financial Counsellors to certify the legitimacy of an individual farmer's Farmhelp Application. We know that in this provision accountants can now certify, but the request of the National Farmers Federation to extend this certification to rural financial counsellors has not been granted. There is another particular request that was made by the National Farmers Federation: Increase the net assets threshold for the re-establishment to $150,000 therefore enhancing the financial capacity of farm families to successhis fully re-establish following exit and reduce the likelihood such individuals will require ongoing welfare support following exit. Nothing has been done. The problem in this particular area is getting worse as asset values rise. I mention this because although we have some definitional tinkering in this piece of legislation, the substance of what farmers require from it has not been addressed by the government. We will be supporting this particular legislation through the parliament but I think it is now a matter of public record that farm organisations are very disappointed in the administration of this area of policy by this minister and by the government.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: FARM HOUSEHOLD SUPPORT
text: Is the amendment seconded? Mr Rudd-I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

Speaker: Mr BROADBENT
Title: FARM HOUSEHOLD SUPPORT
text: Mr Deputy Speaker, of course I am opposed to the amendment, but I will speak to what has just been outlined by the member for Corio, which is the opposition's inability to grasp the importance of this Farm Household Support Amendment Bill 2005 as it affects farmers, particularly in the electorate of MCMillan. More importantly, through the whole of a 30-minute address the member for Corio did not mention one positive statement about what the opposition would do if it were in government. In fact the member for Corio seems very comfortable in opposition. He said that the opposition is broadly supportive of the government's programs. From the list of positives he read out about the government's programs, I would say that the opposition is totally acquiescent to the government's programs, particularly with regard to agriculture. Would the member for Corio, if he were the minister, do anything different from what is being done by this government? I suggest not. Throughout address he was positive about the government's programs. He said that the opposition supports what the government is doing and that the only massive readjustment program was Paul Keating's interest rate regime of 17 to 22½ per cent. That is what changed the industry forever and did so much damage. I want to refer to the member for Corio's address because he did mention one article. I mention another, a very positive article that I will not have time to address. On the Insiders program on Sunday morning there was a woman involved in agriculture, and particularly chemicals, who spoke to the nation through the program about interest rates and how they affect the farming community and the fact that good farmers factor in the range in which interest rates may climb or fall in a given time. Where is the difference between the government and the opposition on interest rates? The range under the Howard government has been between six and eight per cent-rises, drops. Under Labor, interest rates moved between 10 and 17 per cent. So I would not like to take the member for Corio's figuring on his cost to agriculture to this point and then add what it would cost the farming community of Australia under Labor if we were moving between 10 and 17 per cent. However, enough about what the member for Corio has said, because he did not outline where he had a problem with this legislation. We will be positive. This bill is of importance to the seat of MCMillan because MCMillan is dependent on agriculture, with the dairy industry at its heart. Reconstruction and deregulation of the industry have required greater efficiencies with fewer farmers milking more cows and producing more milk. Our dairy industry in Victoria now supplies 63 per cent of Australia's milk production. Further efficiencies, though, are inhibited by a number of measures-and, as the member for Corio mentioned, we have just come out of a prolonged drought. We have a shortage of labour and now in many areas an increase in the cost of land affects the opportunities for neighbouring farmers to buy the land at a reasonable price for viable milk production. The bill may help free up some land by helping farmers on unviable small holdings to take the opportunity to exit the industry. I am reminded today of the mendacity of the member for Corio as he stepped between the cow pats of the dairy herds in MCMillan where he made an offer to local farmers to turn back the clock to 1950. He had a range of statements that he made only in MCMillan. They did not go out of MCMillan because he did not want to spread the news outside the local papers. He got tremendous coverage. He was all over the place. He really led some people to believe that he had the magic pudding in the back of his car for the dairy industry of Australia. But he was misleading the farmers and the people. We have the leaders of Fonterra and other industry leaders saying, ‘We have a great opportunity now to move forward with our dairy industry because of its efficiency and quality.' But we will never be able to supply the markets that are available to us and we will always be looking for new people to come into the industry. How can we do that? This legislation is particularly important to the farmers, particularly dairy farmers, MCMillan because of the dominant role that dairy plays in the total economy of my electorate. Indeed, MCMillan is only one of a small number of federal electorates in which primary industry plays such a dominant role. The agricultural sector in the seat of MCMillan is dominated by the dairy industry, which accounts for almost half of the total farming in the electorate and makes a significant contribution to the state and national economies. MCMillan also boasts a beef cattle industry and a range of smaller agricultural and horticultural sectors, all of which are important contributors to the local economy. The dairy industry in MCMillan is emerging from several years of dry conditions which have had a serious impact on both farm production and employment-and farm families. Despite these leaner years, it continues to make a major contribution to our local economy. Over 1.2 billion litres of milk annually, almost a fifth of Victoria's total production, comes out of the seat of MCMillan. This is a sizeable contribution to the Victorian economy, with the dairy industry accounting for more than $3 billion in domestic sales and more than $2 billion in export sales. These sorts of figures can only be achieved by an industry that is continually striving for greater excellence. The dairy industry has gone through massive reconstruction over the past 30 years. Coming from a dairying community, I have lived with those changes for most of my life, with the greatest reform, outside of the highinterest years of the Hawke-Keating government, coming from deregulation five years ago. Since the 1970s the number of dairy farms has been reduced by more than 50 per cent, while herd numbers and production have increased, so there are fewer farmers milking more cows and using greatly improved manin agement processes. It is the desire of this House and the government that this momentum be maintained. We have to help the industry by creating an environment that makes it possible for the dairy industry to further improve all its management and ways. At the moment global demand for dairy products far outstrips production and, as the world's fourth largest exporter, lia appears well placed to capitalise on this demand, and the dairy farmers in the seat of MCMillan will be best placed of those across the nation to capitalise on this opportunity. In the short time. I have today, Mr Deputy Speaker Baldwin, I want to refer to some of the environmental programs that local farmers are putting in place in MCMillan. Outside of those that are well known to you-the sustainable farms program, Landcare programs and other programs-56 per cent of our dairy farmers have been involved in property revegetation, 64 per cent of our dairy farmers have some remnant vegetation on their properly and 57 per cent of our dairy farmers with waterways have all or most of them fenced off from livestock. Eighty cent of our farmers have formal effluent management systems, and there is potential for a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions through reducing or using the methane gas emitted by cattle, though improved management of organic matter, fertilisers and irrigated pastures will be of importance as the industry moves forward. The opportunity to grow the dairy industry in Australia is before us now. I believe that the opposition is supportive of this bill. I believe that this is opportunity for us-and I know that you have dairy farmers in your electorate, Mr Deputy Speaker-to show that these people are our future and that dairy will be a part Australia's future and a part of Australia's growth and export opportunity.

Speaker: Mr FAWCETT
Title: FARM HOUSEHOLD SUPPORT
text: I rise to support the Farm Household Support Amendment Bill 2005 as tabled by the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry. This bill reinforces the structural adjustment focus of the Farm HelpSupporting Families Through Change program. Farm Help is a program that has been operating since 1997 to provide support to people on farms in severe financial difficulty. AustraSince the program commenced, over 9,000 farmers have received income support and some 8,000 have received advice and training, while over a thousand have received assistance to re-establish themselves outside the farming sector. The government has spent over $187 million on the Farm Help program to date. It has done this because it recognises not only the monetary value of the sector to the Australian economy but also the value that our rural heritage and community bring to Australia as a nation. It also recognises that, while ‘structural adjustment' is a nice succinct academic term, at the end of the day it is real families who are affected by the process and these people deserve our support. Because Australia is a net exporter of agricultural produce, which has traditionally formed a large part of Australia's economic base, there has been investment in the sector over many years. My father, Dr Bob Fawcett, played a key role in this over his working life, developing new technologies and practices for reduced tillage and dryland farming. Increasing sophistication in farm management, meteorological forecasting, market analysis and an ongoing focus on sustainable an land use have increased the potential value of the primary production sector. Despite these advances, those involved are still vulnerable due to factors which are beyond their conof trol. Key amongst these factors are such things as export conditions-the exchange rate, markets, competition, the yields and prices and the vagaries of weather-long term droughts and even short-term events such as cyclones or a late rain. My family has been affected by this, with some members farming north of the Goyder's line in marginal areas where one year in five they are lucky to get a good return on their crops. Others have suffered the changes that have made their small holdings unviable and forced them to move off the land. Farmers whom I represent in Wakefield are prime examples of some of these factors. This year they had a growing concern about the expected yield of cereal crops due to a very late break in the season. When rains did come, many became optimistic that, despite the late start, crops were looking very good. But the unseasonably dry and windy conditions on 12 and 13 October caused significant moisture loss from crops approaching harvest. This led to crop losses and to yield estimates falling by up to 30 per cent in many areas. In some areas, farmers failed to even get their seed back, which represented a significant unexpected loss to their farm businesses given the large investment in fuel, time, herbicides and fertiliser expended in anticipation of at least some return. As well the resulting poor harvest now means a downturn for local business, who were hoping for an ongoing investment in farm infrastructure and machinery maintenance or upgrades. Farmers therefore may face not only the costs of long-term issues such as the compounding effects of land and stock degradation due to drought and the ongoing costs of living outside metropolitan areas but also these unexpected losses in income. At times like these they need support but also certainty-something that this bill will deliver. The government rightly has a focus on getting results for the people of Australia. spite the comments of the member for Corio, the timely introduction of the Farm Help program is one example of where the government saw and responded to a need. The government also has an obligation to exercise good governance over taxpayers' hardearned money, which is why it maintains the Australian National Audit Office and is now responding to the mid-term evaluation report conducted by the Audit Office on this program. The purpose of the amendments contained in this bill is to reinforce the structural adjustment focus of the program and, in doing so, to remove ambiguity about eligibility for assistance. It will do this through: defining a farmer as someone who has a right or an interest in land used for the purposes of farm enterprise; defining that a full-time farmer is one who, for a continuous period of at least two years immediately before applying for the assistance, can demonstrate that more than 50 per cent of their income, capital contributions and work time result from their role as a farmer; recognising that there may be circumstances where a genuine farmer does not in fact meet these criteria due to circumstances beyond their control, and so there is a discretion clause; and, lastly, putting in place penalty provisions to ensure the ongoing integrity of the program by enabling the departmental secretary to notify recipients of their obligation to inform Centrelink if they change their address or choose to reenter farming within five years of being paid the grant. My electorate of Wakefield has been blessed to not suffer some of the long-term drought issues affecting other parts of Australia, but, as a representative of an electorate with a large number of primary producers, I recognise the unique pressures faced by these enterprises and by the families who De- both enable and depend on them. I therefore welcome the renewing of the farm support program for four years as of the last budget and support these proposed amendments to strengthen the legislation which demonstrates this government's commitment to this important sector of our community.

Speaker: Mr BRUCE SCOTT
Title: FARM HOUSEHOLD SUPPORT
text: I rise tonight to speak in this very important debate on the Farm Household Support Amendment Bill 2005. The purpose of this bill is to bring forward amendments to the area of legislation related to the Farm Help program. This program has been running since 1997 and is widely supported by the farm organisations. When we need to make amendments to the program it is important that we do so with the support of the opposition, and I hope we receive that support. Due to the collapse in commodity prices or the unfair trade practices of other countries and the impact that they have on our farm sector, structural adjustment is something that goes on all of the time. As hard as we and our Minister for Trade, who tonight is on his way to China to negotiate the scoping parameters of a free trade agreement with China, fight in this place, international is not always fair. It certainly does not always have a level playing field. So often the impact of unfair trade in the international trading environment is felt by our farmers across Australia. But it is not only the unfair trade practices of some countries that impact on our farm sector; it is also drought. I want to touch on some of the ways extreme drought is impacting on the agricultural and pastoral sectors and on families in my electorate. Since its inception in 1997, the Farm Help program has had tremendous support. An indication of that is the fact that some 9,000 farmers have sought support from this program since its introduction. I think that clearly demonstrates that this program is needed. Just those figures alone suggest the sort of magnitude of support that is going to farmers, and without this program there could well be 9,000 farm families put under even greater stress. Some 8,000 of those 9,000 farmers have received valuable advice and further training in business practices and some 1,000 have accessed the re-establishment grant of up to $50,000. I know from people in my own electorate that it is indeed a very painful process for so many farmers to have reached the point where they need to exit farming and receive that grant. I want to touch on the issue of household support and how it is helping so many families. I mentioned earlier in my comments tonight that farmers are accessing this support, not just because of collapsing commodity prices but because of extreme drought. This government has been very supportive of our farm sector. I am pleased to see the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry enter the chamber. He knows only too well, as a former farmer himself and from his travels around Australia, how this exceptional drought-a once in 100 years eventtrade is impacting on farm families. In the west of my electorate people are now entering their fourth year of extreme drought. Only last week I was in western Queensland, in Longreach, speaking with representatives of Anglicare Central Queensland. They gave me a report of the impact that the exceptional drought is having on the families of this very vast region of central western Queensland. Their experience shows that most property owners are entering their fourth year of drought. They are down to about one-third of their viable stocking levels and their debt-to-equity levels are rising all the time. Notwithstanding that land prices have improved, the debt levels of families are rising faster than the value of their land. So, with the debt-to-equity level rising, families are finding it more difficult to continue to go to the bank and seek additional accommodation. Anglicare pointed out their concern about the social effect that this drought is having on so many families. In their report to me they say that many women are an integral part of the property work force-if I could put it that way-because they are out there working with their husbands and their children, in some cases, just to keep the family business enterprise together. But some of these women have now gone to town to give their children access to education so that the women do not have to supervise their children's education as they did when they were receiving lessons from the School of Distance Education. In other words, the women were being a governess as well as being that extra pair of hands on the drought-stricken property. I was disturbed to receive this report Anglicare. Among some of the references made to me by the drought coordinator for Anglicare Central Queensland were that many of the women in these families just simply cannot cope, as I mentioned earlier, with the role of being a mother, that extra pair of hands and teacher of their children who are being educated from home. The drought is taking a huge toll on these farm and property families and on their lives. Anglicare in western Queensland are continuing to refer many men and women to the Royal Flying Doctor Service mental health unit and to other services-such is the stress that these families are under. The extremely high use of antidepressants is also a very worrying factor. One thing that the drought coordinator said to me was that not only women but more and more men are being referred by Anglicare to the Royal Flying Doctor Service mental health unit, which is based in Longreach. That is why this program is so important. The Farm Help amendments before the House tonight are supporting those families who are under extreme stress. Sometimes when I stand in this House I find it rather hard to describe the mental state of these families and other people who are living in the towns. School numbers continue to fall as people move away from these towns in western Queensland. They have not only dealt with the structural adjustment in the wool industry and with it their declining fortunes but they have seen loss of employment opportunities for the shearers and their families, who have now moved away because of the decline of the wool industry. In Quilpie alone there are now 40 houses for sale. It is a town of about 700 to 800 people. What prospects there are for the sale of those houses, I do not know, but that is the sort of roll-on effect that this exceptional from drought and the decline in fortunes of the wool industry are having on these small country towns. As I said earlier, school numbers are falling in most of those western Queensland towns. It is a reflection of the impact that the structural adjustment and the exceptional drought has had on those families. So many families are being forced off the land through no fault of their own. They have been forced off because of exceptional drought-not bad management. It is not because of bad decisions that they have made; it is because of the exceptional drought. The drought has not broken and the seasonal outlook for this year, sadly, looks as though we are heading into another El Nino effect. That, too, creates enormous stress for those families who are already stressed with trying to cope with the impact of this exceptional drought. The amendments before the House tonight are very worthwhile. I strongly support them. I support the farm household support program because of the way in which it is helping people who need our help. We are a lucky country and we can afford to support families. That is what the Farm Household Support Amendment Bill 2005 is doing: it is supporting families in circumstances where they desperately need our help. The other point I want to raise tonight is how the household support program will help the families of our citrus growers in the Emerald shire in Central Queensland. Those families are being affected by quarantine restrictions that have been placed on that shire because of an outbreak of citrus canker in the citrus industry last year. Those families also need our support. I thank the minister, who is in the House tonight, for his diligence and determination to try to work with the state Minister for Primary Industries and Fisheries in Queensland, Henry Palaszczuk, who just reneged at every point in trying to negotiate a Commonwealth and state joint sharing of the financial support that we need to be giving these farmers affected by an outbreak of citrus canker-not only on their farms but in the region as well-because of the quarantine restrictions apply to these farmers and have had a financial impact it is having. In that region, of the orchardists I spoke to, ready there have been 40 permanent jobs lost. Something like 1,500 workers in the horticultural industry would normally be there working the orchards right now, pruning them for the harvest later this year. They are no longer there because there is no prospect of being able to sell the product on our domestic market, should it come to fruition this year. The only option is to sell this uct into overseas markets, where there are no restrictions on citrus coming from an area that is under quarantine because of the citrus canker outbreak. This program for household support will also help those families, particularly those in my electorate in the quarantine zones. Special provisions that the minister was able to get approved by cabinet will mean farmers will be able to access invaluable household support to support their families. It will also support families from outside the quarantine zone in Queensland if they can demonstrate that they have been affected by the quarantine as it applies in Emerald shire and the impact it has had on the citrus industry in Queensland. I am delighted to have made a contribution to this bill tonight. I say to the other side of the House: we need your support on these issues, because we are supporting families. These amendments to the Farm Household Support Amendment Bill 2005 that amend Farm Help will go a long way to alleviating some of the stress and trauma that families go through when in so many instances they find themselves in situations where they must adjust out of farming and accept the up to $50,000 to help them start a new life. I commend the bill to the House and support this bill and the actions of the government.

Speaker: Mr TRUSS
Title: FARM HOUSEHOLD SUPPORT
text: I thank all of those who have conal- tributed to this debate on the Farm Household Support Amendment Bill 2005 and, in particular, the member for Maranoa, who from the experiences of his own electorate has been able to give a real insight into why this bill is so important. It is, of course, true that there is a large number of Australian farmers who are going through very difficult times because of the drought, including prodmany in your own electorate, Mr Deputy Speaker Baldwin. A range of programs have been put in place to assist Australian farmers. More than 30,000 farm families have benefited from this drought assistance since it began. There has never in Australian history been a greater effort provided by a national government to assist people facing the effects of drought. The Farm Help program also provides assistance in good times to help farmers better prepare for drought, to address the various issues of concern in their industry, to help them deal with the need to improve farm skills and to provide support to those farm families that have to make the very difficult decision about whether or not there is a future for them in the industry. Ongoing programs of this nature I think have a very, very important role to play in ensuring agriculture remains strong and prosperous in our nation. There have been a number of particularly difficult issues to confront as industries face changing world situations, problems in endeavouring to compete and alterations to their regulatory systems which place extreme pressure on some of those industriesparticularly in less favoured areas. But there is nothing more heart breaking for anyone in agriculture than to see their crops die or animals struggling because of the impact of drought. It not just has an economic impact on communities but also depresses their will and kills the spirit of so many in rural and regional Australia. The assistance that is being provided by way of drought aid has helped many families. I am disappointed that there has been a lack of cooperation from the states in the delivery of these arrangements; nonetheless, the Commonwealth has tried to provide real and practical assistance and tens of thousands of Australian farmers have benefited. In relation to this bill, which makes amendments to the Farm Help arrangements, it is particularly important to recognise some of the context in which the Farm Help program exists. The AAA-Agriculture Advancing Australia-program is the government's overarching commitment to all farmers and an ongoing commitment to the development of self-reliant, competitive and sustainable rural industries. AAA began in 1997 and in seven years has provided over $1 billion towards a range of programs to help ensure the long-term prosperity of Australian agriculture and agricultural communities. Over 150,000 primary producers, representing more than half of the Australian agricultural sector, have directly benefited from the package. AAA was renewed in the 200405 federal budget due to its success as a trigger for positive change in rural and regional Australia and in recognition of the considerable assistance it was providing to farming families. Perhaps I could mention on this occasion some of the recent successes of AAA. The Rural Financial Counselling Service, which is funded under the AAA program, has responded promptly after the devastating bushfires on the Eyre Peninsula. I visited that area with the honourable member for Grey just the week before last to announce some new their Commonwealth government assistance to the producers in that region. As soon as the fire had been through, there was a need for some emergency assistance, and the Commonwealth is playing its role in that regard. But many families face the despair of having lost significant parts of their property-and, in some cases, family members and loved ones. The Eastern Eyre Rural Counselling Service located at Tumby Bay, north of the disaster area and the most affected by the bushfire, is providing a focal point for general assistance with the disaster response. Through the South Australian Association of Rural Counselling Services, additional counsellors were deployed into the impacted area on a rotational basis from Kangaroo Island and several other South Australian counselling services. The Rural Financial Counselling Service has been reviewed with a view to further improving the efficiency, timeliness and sustainability of the program and its delivery. What it has been able to do to assist in the South Australian bushfire disaster is an example of how important these services are in rural communities. Farmbis continues to be a key element of the AAA package and last year was renewed for a further four years with a government commitment of up to $66.7 million. The government has been working closely with the states on new program arrangements and has finalised agreements with Western Australia, Victoria, Queensland, Tasmania and South Australia. I am very disappointed at some of the comments being made by the New South Wales minister. We are still waiting for New South Wales to commit to the Farmbis program. Even though they announced with much fanfare funding in their last budget and in subsequent budgets, we now have Minister Macdonald endeavouring to play games and pretend that, somehow or other, he is waiting on a commitment from the Commonwealth in relation to the financial arrangements. That commitment was made ages ago. All of the other states have managed to pick up on that commitment, but New South Wales, in spite of their earlier promises of funding, are obviously looking again at where they are moving. The Northern Territory also have not yet formalised their funding commitments to the program. I hope that, as soon as possible, those remaining states and the Northern Territory will ensure that primary producers and rural land managers continue to benefit from the training opportunities in business and natural resource management skills that are provided by the Farmbis program. The AAA Industry Partnerships program is encouraging industries to be proactive in responding to challenges and opportunities. It is working in partnership with Australia's agricultural, fisheries and forestry industries to assist them to improve their resilience and self-reliance. A key part of the Industry Partto nerships program is the successful Young People in Rural Industries program. Since 2001, the government has provided over $2 million in funding to further the skills, knowledge and participation of young people in rural industries. I have to say that an element of the AAA package that gives me a great deal of satisfaction. To see the talents and the skills of many of the young people who have the potential to make such a significant contribution to Australian agriculture certainly gives me heart and the will to ensure that we provide the kind of environment that can properly reward their enthusiasm and commitment to their industries. A further AAA success has been the Farm Help program. It continues to provide assistance for farmers working towards adjustment. Farm Help has a long record of achievement. Since the program commenced on 1 December 1997, over 9,000 farmers have received Farm Help income support, almost 8,000 farmers have taken up advice and training sessions and over 1,000 farmers have received re-establishment assistance. In that regard, the criticism from the honourable member for Corio of the failure of farmers to take up the exit package is obviously hollow. The member for Corio can surely not have been believing his own words when he criticised the fact that around a thousand farmers have taken up this exit package. He also made reference to the take-up of exit packages specifically provided in particular industries. Is he not aware that 82 farmers so far have already taken up the sugar package re-establishment grants, that 74 took up the Pork Producer Exit Program and well over 140 took up the Dairy Exit Program? There has been a response by farmers unable to continue in the industry to take advantage of these exit programs which help to smooth their passage to an alternative lifestyle. It is not easy for farmers who choose leave the career that has perhaps supported them throughout their lives and may have supported their families for generations. There is a sense of failure in many instances and an uncertainty about their capacity to deal with what a new life might hold in the that is cities or some other places. This re-establishment grant helps farmers to adjust to those circumstances. It gives them an opportunity to undertake some new training and to equip themselves effectively for a new life. The purpose of the Farm Household Support Amendment Bill 2005 is to reinforce the structural adjustment focus of the Farm Help program. It seeks to do this by clarifying qualification provisions for entry to the Help program and by enabling ongoing communication with Farm Help re-establishment grant recipients regarding their undertakings not to re-enter farming and to notify a change of address. These provisions aim to improve the effectiveness of administration of the Farm Help program by allowing for follow-up to determine whether the program has assisted farmers to re-establish successfully out of farming. They are also to ensure that they comply with their agreement not to return to farming within five years of receiving the re-establishment grant. The opposition has indicated support for the bill but has moved a second reading amendment criticising the government for the failure of people to take up the various exit packages, to which I think I have already provided a response. Clearly the opposition amendment is without substance. But I must also refer to the major point the comments on the bill of the member for Corio where he spent a great deal of time criticising the government about interest rates. I am amazed that any member of the Labor Party could come into this parliament and criticise this government on the question of interest rates. Farmers well remember that when Labor was last in government they were paying interest rates of around 23 per cent on their loans. Can anyone imagine in this day and age, when interest rates have been around five, six and seven per cent for an extended period of time, the burden on their mortgage if they were paying the sorts of interest rates that farmers were paying when Labor was last in government-figures like 20 to 23 per cent? No business can sustain that kind of interest rate bill.
