Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION LEGISLATION
text: Jagajaga) (8.46 p.m.)The Higher Education Legislation Amendment (2005 Measures No. 1) Bill 2005 is the fourth bill we have dealt with that tidies up a host of bungles that have now been discovered in the Higher Education Support Act. This is in addition to the hundreds of government amendments moved when the act was originally passed back in December 2003-all this for an act that has only been in force for about nine weeks. When the original legislation was introduced in September 2003, the Minister for Education, Science and Training tried to convince us that we had to pass it without amendment as a matter of urgency. This is the sort of arrogant and sloppy legislation that unfortunately we can expect to see a lot more of once the government has absolute control over the parliament from July this year. The bill before us has four main elements: firstly, to meet funding commitments made in the lead-up to and during the election; secondly, to provide the fourth round of technical amendments associated with the implementation of the Higher Education Support Act passed in December 2003; thirdly, to alter the composition of the governing council of the Australian Maritime College so that it complies with the national governance protocols; and, finally, to give access to table B providers to the capital development pool. I will go through the first part of the lation. The bill includes $48.7 million over four years for the following initiatives: 100 new student places in radiation therapy, 40 new aged care nursing places, 12 new medical places for James Cook University, infrastructure funds for James Cook University, infrastructure funds for the new Australian Maritime College campus at Point Nepean, infrastructure funding for IT for Charles Darwin University, and national institute funding for the Australian National University. The Australian Labor Party support all of these worthwhile initiatives, but we note that many of the commitments are to be delivered to universities in highly marginal coalition held seats. This is an issue I will return to later, but I must say I feel a bit sorry for the universities that do not happen to be located in marginal electorates, and it does call into question the way in which this government allocates funds to our universities. As I indicated, this is the fourth bill to tidy up the mess that the minister presented to this parliament in 2003, and from the look of the program we have even more to come. Every time we look, we are faced with another tidy-up bill to paper over a few more of cracks in what appeared at the time to the minister to be a faultless bill. The technical amendments before us today deal with the following issues. Firstly, they make clear that compliance with the tuition assurance requirements for higher education providers is ongoing, not only at the point of approval. Secondly, they alter the minister's powers to exempt higher education providers from the tuition assurance scheme to allow conditions to be placed on the exemption. Thirdly, they clarify the conditions under which the Howard government's seven-year learning limit must be recredited and the HECS-HELP loan recredlegisited should a provider be unable to offer a unit in which a student is enrolled. Labor will support all of those amendments. The most significant policy issue in the bill is the proposal to give table B providers access to the $43 million a year capital development pool for university infrastructure. Since general capital allocations were rolled into operating grants for universities more than a decade ago, this is now the only capital funding to universities over which the Commonwealth has discretion. The current impact of this section of the bill would be to give Bond University, the University of Notre Dame and Melbourne College of Divinity the ability to apply for grants under the capital development pool. However, this list could grow as additional providers are added to table B in the future. While we will not be opposing this provision, the opposition do have a number of concerns about the lack of transparency and about the way in which this proposal has been introduced. It is important to note at this stage that extending the number of institutions that will be eligible to access the fund without an increase in the size of the fund amounts to a real cut in funding for what is already pretty dilapidated university infrastructure. Like many of my colleagues, I am aware that our universities have countless examples of need for capital development to either expand or replace existing infrastructure. The government in this legislation is cutting the finite pie into a larger number of pieces. Of course, the size of each piece will inevitably get smaller. If the government is serious about providing support where it has not previously done so, it would be good if the government decided to make available increased money as it increases the number of institutions that can apply. It is also worth noting that there was absolutely no prior warning and no public discussion of this initiative prior to the bill's introter's duction to the House just three weeks ago. There was certainly no mention of it before the election and there has been almost no explanation of the rationale for the change, just a pretty bland statement of the outcome. There has been no explanation of where this proposal might sit within the government's broader ideas being floated by the minister at the moment about which higher education institutions are going to be eligible for public subsidies. These are very significant changes that the minister is floating and, as I say, it would be useful to know where this change fits within his thinking. There has been absolutely no discussion about whether this proposal will be used as a precedent to extend funding under more significant programs. There has been no comment on whether the government has similar plans to extend access to other funds to the much more numerous higher education providers outside table B. So we are certainly very keen to hear the government's response to these issues and get a much more detailed rationale from the government to inform consideration by the parliament. I look forward to the minister's response to our concerns when he sums up and to further exploration of his response when the bill reaches the Senate, but in the end we will not be standing in the way of the change. As I said, there was no mention of this proposal to expand the number of institutions eligible for the capital development pool before the election-absolutely no mention at all. You might ask how the minister could have told us about it during the election campaign because he did not actually release a higher education policy. Of all the things we have heard about from the minister, all the kites that have been flown, not one of them was talked about before the election. Maybe it was something that was out of the miniscontrol. We certainly had the impression that the government wanted to talk about anything but the changes that it has now foisted upon our universities and, more particularly, foisted upon students and their families. Students and families are by no means impressed with the government's continuing attempts to expand the number of full fee paying places at our universities. Students and parents do not support the increases in HECS that have now impacted on so many students around the country. Maybe it is no surprise that we had a government that was not prepared to talk about higher education before the election, but it pretty extraordinary that immediately after the election we have a minister who, out in the media, is floating ideas all the time but who made no effort to discuss those with the Australian people before the election. Even if the government had decided to release a policy before the election, you would have to wonder whether anyone would have believed what it said, because the government when it comes to higher education promises before elections certainly has a bit of of giving up on those promises pretty soon after. I remember the now Leader in the Senate promising before the 1996 election that a Howard government would not introduce full fees for Australian undergraduates. One had only to wait until August, following the election in March, for that promise to be ignored-it did not take long at all. The government, of course, decided they would introduce full fees for Australian undergraduates, and now we have fees of up to $210,000 at one university. Students can now buy their way into university, ahead of students with better marks, but of course only if you have these massive sums of money$100,000, $150,000, $200,000-outrageous sums of money, whereby students are jumping the queue and buying a place at university. The government, as I said, have got form. Once again, in 2001, they went to the electorate and promised they would not increase the proportion of full fee paying students. That promise was not worth much. By 2003, the same minister that we have now was announcing his intention to lift the number of full fee payers by increasing the proportion of courses that can be taken up by full fee payers to 50 per cent. This was pulled back somewhat in the Senate to 35 per cent, but we will have to see how long that lasts once is the government has absolute control over the parliament from July this year. We also should not forget that the minister told us in the parliament that the deregulation he was pushing through when he introduced the last round of changes to higher education would not mean huge HECS hikes. He actually had the audacity to say to the parliament: What that means in real terms is that the HECS charge for most courses in most universities will a track record not change at all. Nothing could be further from the truth, as I am sure you are aware, Mr Deputy Speaker. It did not last. Within a year, the vast majority of universities had put their fees up for all possible courses, and most of them by the maximum allowed under the legislation. You would have to say, when it comes to higher education, the government's track record of saying one thing before an election and then doing something completely different is pretty strong. They did not say anything about this clause in the bill before the election; they have just dreamt it up since the election. They did not bother talking to the public about it, and here we have it in a piece of legislation. The other serious concerns that we have about the impact of the government's changes on higher education particularly go to what is happening to the number of places in our universities. Last year, under this government, the number of HECS students actually fell by more than 8,000 while the number of full fee paying places increased by 2,500. What an extraordinary record for a government. The government is very fond of claiming that full fee paying students do not displace a single HECS student. Debate interrupted. NA

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Order! It being 9 p.m., I propose the question: That the House do now adjourn. International Women's Day

Speaker: Ms OWENS
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I rise today to acknowledge the women in my electorate and around the country who every day break down barriers and overcome obstacles to build full lives for themselves their families, women who rise through the ranks, women who break into new career paths for women, women who find ways to mix family with career and women who choose to stay at home and cope with the financial penalties that arise from that choice-the ordinary and extraordinary women who, at a time of changing roles for men and women, work every day to find ways to fashion lives of their own choosing. International Women's Day, 8 March, is just over 30 years old, but the fight by women for women is much, much older than that. Mary Wollstonecraft, who wrote A Vindication of the Rights of Women in 1792, said: I do not wish women to have power over men; but over themselves. She was years, perhaps centuries, ahead of her time, but today her words are absolutely appropriate. Women all around the country and women that I meet every day want and expect power over their own lives, yet we find on a daily basis that there are barriers for women seeking to exercise that powerbarriers that governments have the capacity to overcome. A couple of months ago I met a woman in Rydalmere who had an eight-month-old child. She had put her child on the waiting list at the local child-care centre when she was still pregnant. She did not have a car; she needed to use the local centre. When the child was eight months old, she planned on going back to work, so she started looking for work. She found work that would start two months after that. A month before she was due to start work, the local child-care centre phoned and offered her a place for her child. At that stage, because she had not started work, she could not afford the fees, so she said, ‘Can I delay it for a month?' The child-care centre said, ‘No, we have to give and the place away.' A month later, when she tried to start work, she could not find child care for her child. When she had child care she could not afford it; when she could afford it she did not have child care. So this is a woman who remained out of the work force and is still out of the work force while she tries to find a child-care place and a job which appears in the same week. I met another woman raising three children on her own who was desperate to go back to work and had the skills to go back to work, but because of the way the family payments and the tax system are structured the day she went back to work she was worse off. If she could have afforded to have been worse off, she would have gone back to work, but she simply could not afford it. So there was a woman with the skill and the will to work who was trapped by her circumstances. When I meet with businesswomen I am astonished at how often a group of quite senior businesswomen will sit around talking about the difficulties they have with child care. Even given the opportunity to talk about business, when meeting with senior business figures their main priority is how difficult they find it to balance their careers with child care. When I go to a child-care centre expecting to talk about child care, I am amazed at how often I find myself talking to women about how difficult they find it to find work. So it does not matter whether you are talking to women without work or women with work, the issue remains the same: it is about ways to find a balance between children and career. It also is apparent that women are the first to suffer from any downturn in conditions-a downturn in the economy or in working conditions. When the labour force is increasingly casualised, it is women who are the first into the ranks of casual labour. It is women who first suffer that lack of security and income. When we do not provide appropriately for the aged, it is women who drop out of the work force to care for their parents first. It is women who bear the burden of downturns. But, as I said earlier, Mary Wollstonecraft, well ahead of her time, got it absolutely right. I know from my conversations with many women that they expect us to get it right. They expect us in this House to make it possible for them to do what they know they need to do with their lives, which is to build lives that suit them. Whether they choose to stay home or go back to work, whether they choose to go back full time or part time, whether they choose a casual work lifestyle or a part-time work lifestyle, they expect us to take the barriers down so that they can actually make their own choices and build their own lives. Bishop David Chislett

Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I rise in the House today to congratulate the Right Reverend David Chislett SSC, the Rector of All Saints Anglican Church, Brisbane, on his consecration as a bishop in the Church of God on 16 February 2005 at the Parish Church of the Good Shepherd, Rosemont, Philadelphia, in the United States of America. I know Bishop Chislett very well. I have attended All Saints Wickham Terrace for years, first when I was a student at secondary school. I am a former altar server, parish councillor and synodsperson. Bishop Chislett was consecrated to serve the traditional Anglicans in this country and Forward in Faith Australia who are dismayed at the heterodox views of many of the Anglican bishops in this country. Bishop Chislett will work with the Traditional Anglican Communion to bring orthodox Anglicanism to a new future. The chief consecrator was Archbishop John Hepworth, the Australian Primate of the Traditional Anglican Communion, and there were a number of coconsecrators, including the Anglican Bishop of the Murray, the Right Reverend Ross Davies, and the Anglican Bishop of Ruvuma in Tanzania, Bishop Kapinga. It is important to recognise that the Anglican Church over the years has always claimed to be part of the One Holy Catholic and Apostolic Church, and in fact the threefold order of ministry is the same as in the great communions of the West and the East-that is, the Roman Catholic Church and the Churches of Eastern Orthodoxy. I am indebted to the Bishop of the Murray, who participated in the consecration, for some of the remarks I am about to make. I was always taught that the Anglican Church is the Catholic Church of England but, regrettably, in 1992 the Church of England broke with Catholic order when it legislated to allow for women to be ordained to the apostolic ministry of the priesthood. In the same year the Anglican Church of Australia enacted similar legislation. Traditional Anglicans would consider this to be a breach of Catholic tradition and Catholic order, and in fact it does present a situation in the Anglican Communion today in which we have impaired communion and where many bishops and people feel unable to be totally in communion with all in the Canterbury Anglican Communion. In England when this occurred in 1992 there was a provision made for provincial episcopal visitors, and a number of ‘flying bishops' were appointed to minister to those congregations that were not able to accept the ministry of their bishop who had ordained women, thereby leaving the Catholic faith. In the Australian spirit of a fair go it unreasonable that the Anglican Church in Australia should have made a similar provision for those Anglicans who, in all conscientiousness, were unable to accept the departure from Catholic order. I have observed the ministry of Bishop Chislett at All Saints Wickham Terrace. I have seen him build a congregation which was quite small into one that every Sunday now has more communicants at high mass than St Johns Anglican Cathedral in Brisbane. He has pastoral gifts, principles, integrity and is someone who should be held up as a role model for all Anglican clergy. Bishop Chislett will continue as the Rector of All Saints Wickham Terrace while carrying out his new episcopal ministry on behalf of traditional Anglicans in this country and Forward in Faith Australia. He will also work as part of the Traditional Anglican Communion and the Anglican Catholic Church in Australia. I commend Bishop Ross Davies for his courage in participating in this consecration, along with the other bishops. Bishop Chislett is an example to all of us. He is an outstanding pastor and for 10 years has served conscientiously as the Rector of All Saints Wickham Terrace and he is a person who will enhance the future of Anglicanism in this country. Bishop Chislett understands the Anglican Church is the English expression of the Catholic faith. He is quite uncompromising and highly principled. He is a person I want to salute in the federal parliament as a person who should enjoy the admiration of all of us. International Women's Day

Speaker: Mrs ELLIOT
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I am very proud to rise and speak on behalf of the women of Richmond to mark International Women's Day. In talking to many women across my electorate I find that opis not portunity is a common theme of our discussions. Women want the opportunity to further their education, to balance work and family commitments and to access decent health care when they need it and when their families need it. Of course, all of this is made a lot easier when women live in a safe and secure environment. Late last year I met with the women who run the Tweed Shire Women's Service. They provide support, counselling and a safe haven for women who have been the victims of domestic violence. When I was a police officer, the sad truth was that I spent a great deal of my time attending domestic violence situations. In my experience, when women live in a safe and supportive environment it is only then that they can find real opportunities. Let me turn to another issue that, because of this government's complacency, is limiting opportunities for women. Across my electorate there is a shortage of child-care places. We are the second fastest growing region in the country, and I speak to families every week that are waiting to get their children into child care. For too long child care has been underfunded and, on top of this, it is becoming increasingly unaffordable for working families. In another broken promise to families in my electorate, the Howard government has reneged on its pledge to pay a 30 per cent tax rebate on child care this year. Now, families will be forced to wait until July 2006. The Prime Minister is so out of touch with ordinary working families that he has failed to deliver this much-needed relief. This government has indeed become so complacent that it no longer believes it should keep its promises to Australian families. Parents are battling to get their babies and toddlers into long day care and family day care, and when those kids go on to school there is a shortage of available vacation and after school care. I recently visited a local child-care facility that provides after school care and vacation care. The manager of the centre told me she was literally overrun with parents wanting to put their children into vacation care. She simply could not cater to them and had to turn so many of them away. This often means that working families have to find alternatives that simply do not exist. One solution is to provide more funding and therefore more child-care places. Child care has been neglected; it is as simple as that. As a mother of two young children, Alexandra, who is 6, and Joe, who is 5, I know that the reality is that a lack of child care limits opportunities for women. In 2005 women should not have to choose between continuing their career or education and having a family. If they choose to stay at home with their families, they should be able to do so without feeling financial pressure to go back to work straight away. But the government's broken promise has only added to that pressure. These are not just women's issues; they are also community issues. Women make up more than half the population. It stands to reason that issues affecting us affect the tire community. It is unfortunate that women are paying the price for this government's complacency. I also often speak to many elderly women who have so much difficulty in accessing health care, decent dental care and home care, and they have difficulty in finding places in aged care centres as well. There is a whole range of issues in relation to women that are so important, and I have been very proud to stand here today and speak on behalf of the women of Richmond. Roads: Brisbane Urban Corridor

Speaker: Mr VASTA
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I rise to speak about the effects of truck traffic on residents of the Bonner electorate. In particular, I wish to draw attention to a notorious section of the national freight route known as the Brisbane urban corridor, the BUC. To residents of my electorate the BUC is more commonly known as the Mount GravattCapalaba Road. This is not a new issue. It first surfaced in the early 1990s and it has continued to be of great concern to the local residents ever since. It is no coincidence that I have chosen this to be the first matter that I have raised in the House. This issue is as important to me as it is to my constituents. The Brisbane urban corridor cuts across Brisbane's southern suburbs and links the Ipswich Motorway to the Gateway Motorway. This 11-kilometre corridor includes Mount Gravatt-Capalaba Road, Kessels Road, Riawena Road and Granard Road. It is a road corridor that was clearly not designed to carry the traffic it now carries. Each day up to 50,000 vehicles travel on this route. Although there are many different users of the BUC, there is no doubt that truck traffic has the greatest impact on the surrounding suburbs. In the Bonner electorate, residents of suburbs like Wishart, Upper Mount Gravatt, en- Mansfield and Eight Mile Plains have to live with the effects of this traffic every day. It has a major impact on their quality of life. This is a fact that nobody disputes. Elected representatives from all levels of government and from both major political parties are united in their recognition that truck traffic on the BUC is a serious problem. In particular, I wish to acknowledge the efforts of my colleagues the honourable member for Moreton, Mr Gary Hardgrave, and the councillor for Wishart, Mr Graham Quirk, who have fought tirelessly for around a decade to highlight the need for action on this issue. In 2002 the Howard government demonstrated their commitment to local residents by funding a major study aimed at finding solutions to the problems on the BUC. This study received feedback from close to 2,000 people, and more than 20 separate community meetings were held during the process. The results of this study confirmed what residents already knew: truck traffic was a problem that impacted on their daily lives in a major way. One local family who participated in the study commented, ‘Traffic, pollution and trucks make our life miserable.' Although this is the comment of just a single family, I know that it reflects the feelings of thousands of people living along the BUC. The outcome of this planning study was a series of recommendations aimed at improving traffic conditions and reducing the amount of heavy vehicle traffic on the BUC. I am pleased to report that two of the most important recommendations to come out of the study are being implemented as I speak. Starting on 28 February, a 12-month trial commenced to allow trucks to travel toll free at night on the Gateway Motorway extension and the Logan Motorway. These toll roads are the major alternative routes to the BUC. The study found that many truckies were using the BUC to avoid the motorway tolls. This trial is aimed at getting non-local and non-essential truck traffic off the BUC when residents are trying to sleep. In addition to this trial, new number plate recognition cameras have been installed on Mount Gravatt-Capalaba Road to monitor traffic. These cameras will help us to identify overloaded trucks, oversized trucks, speeding trucks, noisy trucks and polluting trucks. The cameras will also help us to determine the effectiveness of the toll-free trial. In short time since the trial started I have already received some very encouraging feedback. One Upper Mount Gravatt resident told me that even after just four nights he had noticed a dramatic reduction in traffic noise and truck traffic. I have had similar feedback from other residents. While we still have a long way to go, I am delighted that we have now taken the first crucial steps towards achieving better outcomes for residents living along the BUC. I look forward to working with local residents and my federal and state colleagues to ensure that we continue to make progress over the coming months and years. International Women's Day

Speaker: Ms HOARE
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Charlton) (9.19 p.m.)Today, 8 March 2005, women in this place, in our home towns, across this nation and throughout the world celebrate International Women's Day. I pay tribute and my respects to Indigenous women around the country who are still struggling for equality and justice in the areas of health, education and employment. I also pay tribute to the members of the Newcastle branch of the Union of Australian Women. All of us have older women in our electorates who were in the midst of the major struggles to try to achieve justice and equity for themselves and their generation but more particularly for their daughters and their granddaughters. These are the women of the Save Our Sons campaign, who protested against Australia's involvement in the Vietnam War, and they are still actively protesting against violence in all forms including Australia's involvement in Iraq. Their grandmothers fought for the right to vote for women; they fought against discrimination against women and for free and accessible education and equal wages for women. Unfortunately, today women still lag far behind the men in wages, are still under represented in our parliaments and do not sit in equal numbers as CEOs or executive officers of our major companies. Women still carry the greater responsibility for child rearing, housework and caring for elderly parents-to name but a few. Another major struggle of our grandmothers and mothers was, and is, that relating to women's reproductive rights and women's rights to control their own fertility. Unfortupoor nately, the Australian public has been once again assailed with the abortion debate. Who raised and who is leading the current debate about reproductive rights in this country? Some conservatives and some church leaders, led by none other than Australia's selfappointed morals crusader, the Minister for Health and Ageing. Be afraid; be very afraid. We have here a minister for health in a conservative government who is vehemently opposed to women having control of their own fertility and reproductive rights. Women's access to safe, legal abortion is a major public health issue. Mortality from abortions has declined since 1971, when many states changed their legislation to provide some protection for abortion providers. Prior to 1971, abortion was a major cause of death related to pregnancy, with an average of 25 per cent of maternal deaths being attributed to abortion. Since 1971 deaths associated with abortion are rare. The World Health Organisation estimates that globally 19 million unsafe abortions take place each year and that 68,000 women die as a consequence of this. The majority of unsafe abortions occur in developing countries where unsafe abortions are characterised by unskilled or undertrained practitioners, unsanitary facilities, a lack of post-abortion care and hazardous techniques. The WHO characterises unsafe abortion as one of the neglected public health problems in developing countries. Unwanted and unplanned pregnancy is linked to a range of social, cultural, economic and psychological factors. Of course, we know there are no simple solutions that will reduce the rate of abortions-and taking Medicare funding from the procedure is not the very least of them. This so-called solution, promoted by anti-abortionists, would only serve to deny access to abortions for and rural women, therefore allowing only wealthy women to terminate unplanned or unwanted pregnancies. There is evidence which indicates that comprehensive sex education and access to contraception are effective in lowering the rates of pregnancy, particularly amongst young women. Comprehensive sex education does provide young people with more support and guidance to delay their first sexual intercourse and develop a healthy attitude towards sex and sexuality. There is no evidence that abstinence-only programs successfully delay the onset of sexual intercourse. In fact, abstinence-only programs undermine the use of contraceptives once young people become sexually active. Abortion is the only widely practiced medical procedure that is criminalised in this country. The termination of pregnancy is contained under the Criminal Law in every state and territory except the ACT. Recent data from the Australian Survey of Social Attitudes show that 81.2 per cent of Australians, regardless of gender or religion, agree that women should have the right to choose an abortion. Some 42.4 per cent of Australians strongly agree and 38.8 per cent agree that women should have the right to choose an abortion. Only nine per cent of Australians either disagree or strongly disagree that women should have the right to choose an abortion. I conclude by reminding the House of Labor's platform concerning reproductive rights. It reads: As women are the major users of health and community services, Labor will: … … … support the rights of women to determine their own reproductive lives, particularly the right to choose appropriate fertility control and abortion(Time expired) Hasluck Electorate: Commonwealth Land

Speaker: Mr HENRY
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Hasluck) (9.24 p.m.)During the recent election campaign and in my first speech in this House, I indicated that I would act without fear or favour on behalf of the residents of Hasluck. There is considerable concern amongst constituents and residents in my electorate about the proposal to build a brickworks on Commonwealth land which is currently leased by the Westralia Airports Corporation and is immediately adjacent to the Perth airport. I understand that a couple of weeks ago a notice, effective from 14 February, was served on the West Aviat Golf Club on Kalamunda Road, South Guildford, by the Westralia Airports Corporation Pty Ltd. It gave the West Aviat Golf Club only 30 days-just one month-to vacate the property, with all that that entails. This is allegedly so that the land can be used to build a brickworks. I find it rather amazing that a group of people can be treated so harshly by any organisation. These constituents and residents have lived in the area for a long time and have leased the golf course area since 1984 for that particular purpose. They have put their own blood, sweat and tears into creating this golf course at their own expense and through their own efforts. They have created an excellent recreational area for use by residents. I have had representations on these issues from councillors of the City of Swan, from Kalamunda Shire and from representatives of local community associations from High Wycombe, Hazelmere and Rose Hill expressing concerns about health, safety and the environment, and the impacts that these potential arrangements will have on their amenity. I have received many emails and have spoken with many residents about their concerns. Their concerns about the proposed development of the brickworks on the site include the lack of a consultative planning process; the potential environmental impacts on adjacent residential areas, lakes and wetlands; and the safety to aircraft from the heat emitted from the chimney stacks of the proposed brickworks and from the nearby asphalt plant. Importantly, they are concerned about their health and the air quality resulting from the emissions. In addition, on land adjacent to this area there is a waste material dump site, previously used as a building waste recycling operation. It is alleged that asbestos is contained in this waste dump, and they are concerned about the potential threat and hazard of that. I would like to read from some of the emails I have received: We appeal to you, as a representative of the federal government, to block the moves being made at present to build another brickworks in the Midland environs, of which Hazelmere forms a part, on the West Aviat Golf Club, which club members have constructed with their own hands and, out of their own toil and labour, have maintained a beautiful landscaped area, incorporating two man-made lakes, which are visited by birds of many varieties. Please give this appeal your urgent consideration and try to get your colleague the Hon. John Anderson to rethink the matter and get WAC to leave us on the land which we have invested so much in by way of money, blood, sweat and frustration only to have it taken away from us in just four weeks. According to the honour book, over 6,000 members of the public used the course last year. In 1984 the land was leased to Transport Australia institute, the parent body of the West Aviat Golf Club, which was built and maintained by the members on a purely voluntary basis and still is. The site is marked on the airport master plan as precinct 3 and was previously zoned as recreation and sport. It was vested by the federal government of the day back in the 1940s and is used as a camp for country people to send their kids to today. I assure the residents and my constituents in Hasluck that I will work as hard as I possibly can to achieve the best possible outcome for our community in this matter. I have made representations to the appropriate minister and will pursue those issues on their behalf. (Time expired)
